headline: Dan Ashworth has clever Man Utd transfer plan in bid to land Raheem Sterling deal
body: Manchester United and Chelsea have been exploring a swap deal which would see Raheem Sterling trade Stamford Bridge for Old Trafford after losing his starting spot
Dan Ashworth has been working on a deal which would see Manchester United bring Raheem Sterling to Old Trafford without paying an initial outlay, it has been claimed

Ashworth, who took over as United's sporting director this summer, has already overseen several new signings. Manuel Ugarte is set to become the fifth senior player to join during the current transfer window once his move from Paris Saint-Germain is made official for an initial £42m.

Sterling could become number six, with talks opened over a potential swap deal. Jadon Sancho could move to Chelsea as part of an agreement, in a move which would allow both clubs to dispense with out-of-favour wingers.

With United already spending big on their new signings, though, Ashworth has recognised the need to be smart when it comes to any remaining deal. With Chelsea already making it clear Sterling would struggle for game time in West London, the ball appears to be in their rivals' court.

According to The Telegraph, United are determined to pay no outlay for Sterling. The aim comes against the backdrop of the expectation that Chelsea would cover the bulk of Sterling's wages to allow him to leave Stamford Bridge.
Sterling still has three years left on his £300,000-per-week deal in West London. Sancho, meanwhile, has two years remaining on the deal he signed when he joined United in 2021.

Sancho returned to Dortmund on loan for the second half of last season, helping the team reach the Champions League final. A permanent switch didn't follow, though he made his first United appearance in close to a year during pre-season.

Sterling, with 123 Premier League goals, is the third-highest scoring player still active in the competition. Only Jamie Vardy (137) and Mohamed Salah (159) have more than the England international, though he has only scored 14 league goals in his two Chelsea seasons.

After featuring in pre-season for the Blues, Sterling was left out of the matchday squad for the Premier League opener against his former club Manchester City. Speaking after the game, manager Enzo Maresca lifted the lid on the situation affecting the out-of-favour stars in the Blues' bloated squad.

“I'm not saying Raheem is not a good player but I prefer different kinds of wingers.This is the reason why," Maresca said. “I spoke with Raheem, one-on-one the day before City and I explained him exactly the situation. I didn't see Raheem after the game.

“In this moment, they (Sterling and Ben Chilwell) are training apart. The situation with them both is quite clear. There is not any update on their situations. In case I sit with Raheem, I will tell him exactly the same things that I already told him. I don’t have anything new to tell him because I was quite clear.”

headline: What happened to Man Utd's three 'mood killers' with Erik ten Hag offloading two of them
body: Manchester United have had countless big names come and go in the transfer market, but three in particular were deemed to be a negative influence in the dressing room not too long ago
Manchester United have seen a host of big players come and go in recent times.

But there's three players the club were reportedly eager to get rid of due to having a "bad influence" on the dressing room. Paul Pogba and Anthony Martial were mainstays in the United side for several years, while Edinson Cavani also excited fans when he arrived from Paris Saint-Germain, yet all three were shown the exit door at United after turmoil behind the scenes.

It was previously reported how former interim manager Ralf Rangnick was looking to get shut of the trio due to them possessing a disruptive influence. They were also allegedly 'killing the mood' in the United camp.
So, what became of the players that Ragnick and his successor Erik ten Hag seemed eager to move on. Mirror Football takes a look.

Cavani became a hit with the United faithful after he netted 17 times in his debut season at Old Trafford. However, a dismal second season saw the player not only give his number 7 shirt up to Cristiano Ronaldo but only play 15 games due to injury.

Things took a turn for the worse when on several occasions, it was deemed that Cavani effectively ruled himself out of games through injury, leaving United legend Paul Scholes to even brand him a “disgrace”. Rangnick grew impatient with the player and, along with Pogba and Martial, accused the 37-year-old of destabilising the atmosphere at United, according to German outlet Bild.
In May 2022, Rangnick bid goodbye to Cavani in a United shirt, with the player then signing for Valencia. The Uruguayan star lasted a season back in Spain before he joined Boca Juniors in Argentina.
Upon leaving, Cavani thanked United supporters but claimed that he "wanted to contribute more this season", referring to his second underwhelming campaign for the Red Devils.
Pogba, who had two stints at United, left to rejoin Juventus in the summer of 2022 after a difficult spell back at Old Trafford.

Jose Mourinho re-signed Pogba for United in a deal worth nearly £90m, with the star's mega-money move preceding what was meant to be a new fruitful period for the club post-Sir Alex Ferguson. What followed, however, was six years of managerial fallouts, disputes with team-mates and moments of tension with United fans.

Nevertheless, his fractured time at the club was punctuated with fleeting moments of brilliance. Pogba then returned to Juventus on a four-year deal after Ten Hag deemed him surplus to requirements. However, his time in Italy was beset with injury.

His career then took a turn for the worse as he was banned from football for four years. The midfielder tested positive for DHEA, a banned substance that boosts endogenous testosterone. Pogba and his camp have always maintained innocence and that the taking of any prohibited substance was never intentional.
In a statement he said: “I have today been informed of the Tribunale Nazionale Antidoping's decision and believe that the verdict is incorrect.

"I am sad, shocked and heartbroken that everything I have built in my professional playing career has been taken away from me. When I am free of legal restrictions the full story will become clear, but I have never knowingly or deliberately taken any supplements that violate anti-doping regulations."

Martial joined United from Monaco in 2015 and endeared himself to the United crowd when he scored a sensational goal on his debut against Liverpool in a thrilling 3-1 victory. The Frenchman spent several years at United where he scored 90 goals in over 317 appearances.
He remained a key player for his first few seasons at United, with his 23 goals in the 2019/20 campaign a career-best. However, dips in form and injuries plagued his final few years at Old Trafford.
His time at United was largely drama free - until he clashed with Rangnick. After being accused by the German of refusing to play, Martial hit back on Instagram.
"I will never refuse to play a match for Man United," he said. "I've been here for seven years and I never disrespected and never will disrespect the club and the fans."
The player joined Spanish side Sevilla on-loan for the second-half of the 2021/22 campaign, and upon his return, he never became a permanent figure in the side under Ten Hag.

He is now a free agent as he weighs up his next move, with Sky Sports reporting that a return to his homeland appears to be the most likely destination. Ligue 1 rivals Lyon and Marseille, who snapped up Mason Greenwood just a few weeks ago, are both interested in landing in the 28-year-old.

headline: Man Utd target who rejected Erik ten Hag handed £25m Premier League transfer lifeline
body: Nottingham Forest are looking to bring in a striker before the transfer window closes and Ajax's Brian Brobbey - who was once linked with Manchester United - has emerged as a potential target
Nottingham Forest have put Brian Brobbey on their list of potential striker signings before Friday’s transfer window slams shut.
The Midlands club are in the market for a forward after a deal to sign Arsenal front man Eddie Nketiah collapsed over personal terms between the club and the player.
It is understood that Ajax forward Brobbey is one of a number of forwards they are looking at this week as they ponder a late move.
Brobbey, 22, could be on the market for around £25m. Ajax are looking to strengthen their squad before the deadline and the Dutch striker is one player they could be enticed into selling.

The Dutchman scored 22 goals and had 12 assists in 43 appearances last season but the Eredivisie giants are trying to secure a deal for Wout Weghorst from Burnley while Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain has also been linked with a move there.

Ajax would need to sell before they can buy in the final days of the window. Brobbey is interested in a move to the Premier League and has previously been linked to Arsenal and Manchester United. The Red Devils even considered a swoop this summer, the despite the fact the striker previously rejected Erik ten Hag.

Nketiah had been in talks over a £30million move to Nottingham Forest, but that broke down after personal terms could not be agreed. Marseille were also interested in the striker, but that deal also collapsed and they have since signed Elye Wahi from Lens instead.

Crystal Palace have made an approach for Nketiah. It is claimed that the England international is open to joining them and talks are ongoing over personal terms, although several other clubs are also interested.

Along with the departure of Jordan Ayew, Palace have also sold Michael Olise to Bayern Munich and Joachim Andersen to Fulham. Chadi Riad, Ismaila Sarr and Daichi Kamada have been brought in to strengthen the squad, but manager Oliver Glasner admits more new faces are needed.

headline: Man Utd open Raheem Sterling transfer talks as stance on Jadon Sancho swap deal emerges
body: Raheem Sterling is out of favour at Chelsea, who have begun working on a potential exit for the England international, and Manchester United's stance has become clear
Manchester United are exploring a deal for Chelsea's Raheem Sterling, it has been claimed, but a swap involving Jadon Sancho might not be entirely straighforward.

England international wingers Sterling and Sancho are both out of favour at their respective clubs. Neither man has featured in the Premier League this season, though United star Sancho - thought to be of interest to Chelsea - had a brief run-out in the Community Shield.

Sterling sought clarity from Chelsea after being left out of their matchday squad for the opening weekend of the season against Manchester City. The forner City man saw his opportunities limited after a busy summer, with Pedro Neto among the additions to Chelsea's squad under new manager Enzo Maresco, and Joao Felix has been added since that opening game.

Sancho spent the second half of last season on loan at Borussia Dortmund after a public falling-out with United boss Erik ten Hag. The pair appeared to patch up their differences during the close-season, but a suitable offer could still tempt Ten Hag to allow the player to leave.

According to The Telegraph, United's sporting director Dan Ashworth has held talks with Chelsea representatives over a potential swap deal involving Sterling and Sancho. However, the Manchester club are said to only be prepared to sanction an exit for their player on their own terms.
“I spoke with Raheem, one-on-one the day before City and I explained him exactly the situation. I didn't see Raheem after the game," Chelsea boss Maresca said of the 29-year-old.
“In this moment, they (Sterling and Ben Chilwell) are training apart. The situation with them both is quite clear. There is not any update on their situations.”
Ten Hag was asked about Sancho before United's defeat to Brighton in their second game of the new league season. "He’s here, but I have a choice to make," he said.

"We had some issues, but we need a full squad. He’s one of them and he has to compete for his position and game to game we will have a look. But in the squad every position we need double because it’s going to be a long season."

United are poised to make Manuel Ugarte their fifth summer signing. The Uruguay international, who will join from Paris Saint-Germain, follows Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Noussair Mazraoui and Matthijs de Ligt in moving to Old Trafford.

headline: opinionMan Utd feel transfer window has been big success as Manuel Ugarte set to sign
body: Manuel Ugarte is joining for £51million to take Manchester United's summer spend to £200m and the Reds are delighted with all the transfer business they have done
They’re not going to have an open-top bus parade, but Manchester United are very pleased with their summer transfer business with Manuel Ugarte becoming their fifth major signing.

Ugarte, 23, is finally, finally, joining from Paris St Germain for an initial £42.2million, with a further £8.4million in adds-ons, to allow both United and the Ligue 1 giants to say they got what they wanted. PSG should eventually get the £51million they demanded and which they paid Sporting Lisbon for him last year.

United can point to the £42.2million up front fee and they have paid what they wanted all along. United identified Ugarte early in the window and feel the Uruguay midfielder, who began his medical on Tuesday before signing a five-year deal, can be a star for them after he was named in the Best XI at this summer’s Copa America.

Ugarte will take their spending close to £200million for the summer and the Reds feel they have strengthened in all the positions they targeted. In signing Leny Yoro, 18, Joshua Zirkzee, 23, Matthjis de Ligt, 25, and Noussair Mazraoui, 26, they have also bought players with experience with their best years ahead of them.

They have reduced the average age of their squad and boss Erik ten Hag will ease Harry Maguire, Victor Lindelof and Jonny Evans out of his defence over the course of this season. Ten Hag has big hopes for de Ligt and Mazraoui and sees the Dutchman as partnering Lisandro Martinez in the heart of their defence with the Tunisia defender operating at right-back.

Yoro is one for the future and United see him blossoming into becoming a regular for France and United at centre-half. Ugarte will partner Kobbie Mainoo in the midfield holding role with Zirkzee supporting striker Rasmus Hojlund.

Ten Hag can see his vision for United coming together and the club have strengthened in all the areas he wanted. Going out, United have brought in £75million from the likes of Mason Greenwood, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Scott McTominay leaving.

McTominay, who also began his medical on Tuesday, is joining Napoli for £25million, ending his 22 year-association with United and he first joined the club as a five-year-old. Their last big-name departure could be Jadon Sancho and the winger could go before Friday’s transfer deadline.

Juventus are talking to United over Sancho, who has been welcomed back into the fold by ten Hag after their spectacular fall-out last season. However the Serie A side are not coming up with the numbers United want and the Old Trafford outfit will only accept loan offers if there is an obligation to buy.

United paid Borussia Dortmund £73million for Sancho and accepting a loan offer with no commitment to make the deal permanent could see him returning to Old Trafford next July with just 12 months left on his contract. Chelsea are also interested in Sancho, but would like United to sign Sterling in return, which is not going to happen.
With United having fulfilled their side of the bargain, it is over to ten Hag to deliver the Champions League football they crave.

headline: Man Utd risk Sir Alex Ferguson's wrath after agreeing to sell Scott McTominay for £25.4m
body: Manchester United's decision to cash in on Scott McTominay may not have gone down well with Sir Alex Ferguson, the man who brought the midfielder to the club
Manchester United may have upset Sir Alex Ferguson with their decision to sell Scott McTominay.

The Scotland midfielder, 27, who has been associated with United since childhood, is set to undergo a medical with Napoli, who have had a bid of £25.4million accepted. McTominay has been used as a substitute in all three of United’s games so far this season but made 43 appearances in the 2023/24 campaign, including a start in the 2-1 FA Cup final victory over Manchester City in May.

The academy graduate, who made his senior debut against Arsenal in 2017, signed a five-year contract with the option of a further 12 months in June 2020. However, he has been deemed expendable by Erik ten Hag, who is now set to land long-term midfield target Manuel Ugarte from Paris Saint-Germain.

After lengthy negotiations with PSG, United have finally agreed a fee of €50m (£42.3m), with a further €10m (£8.5m) in add-ons. McTominay's departure will be disappointing for many at Old Trafford, possibly including compatriot Ferguson, who signed a young McTominay and has previously hailed the midfielder’s big-game temperament.

Speaking to the Scottish FA in 2021, Ferguson said: “Scott McTominay is now emerging as one of Man United's big players. When you watch Man United pick their team for a big game, McTominay's name is in it. He's a good character, a great trainer. I know a little bit about the boy and I think that's the background.”
Comparing McTominay to another United stalwart, Ferguson added: “I signed him when he was seven or eight years of age and he was actually a centre-forward as a kid.
"He's just sprouted, a little bit like Darren Fletcher – Darren had a few little annoying injuries as he was growing and needed some rest periods and things like that.

“McTominay is of a similar type to Darren – long, lanky, good winner of the ball and a good turn of pace going forward, a great attitude to the game. All these attitudes that Darren Fletcher had, he's got them.
“Even if you go back to my time with Darren, I very seldom left him out of big games, particularly against Arsenal. He was fantastic against Arsenal and [Patrick] Vieira and I had no problems.
“McTominay is going forward on those guidelines that Darren pursued for a long time at United. It's really rewarding for me to see a Scot coming through.”

headline: Liverpool fans left fuming as Premier League announce referee for Man Utd fixture
body: Liverpool travel to Manchester United on Sunday in the biggest game of this weekend's round of Premier League matches, but Reds fans are already fearing the worst
Liverpool fans have been left furious after Anthony Taylor was appointed to referee their clash against Manchester United this weekend.

The Reds travel to Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon in the final game of the third week of the Premier League season. New boss Arne Slot has won both of his games so far this campaign, against Ipswich and Brentford.
United meanwhile have had a mixed opening to the new campaign, barely beating Fulham before losing to Brighton. Sunday's game will be Slot's biggest so far since he replaced Jurgen Klopp as manager.

But Liverpool supporters are already fearing the worst after Taylor was announced as referee. It is the fifth time he will take charge of this fixture, having also been in the middle for the 2-2 draw at Old Trafford last season, the Reds’ 4-2 and 5-0 wins in 2020/21 and 2021/22 respectively and a 0-0 draw at Anfield in 2016.
Despite Liverpool's unbeaten record with Taylor as referee, Reds fans have been left fuming. One said: "And here it goes again. Sigh." Another added: "Expect controversy in this one."

A third said: "Of course he will, honestly how does he get these games." A fourth fumed: "Wow. We know what to expect. We can start writing our petitions now." A fifth said: "This big fraud..... I so much dislike him."
Another added: "Too early for drama. EPL will never change." A seventh fan said: "Life is going well, and then something like this happens." While a final supporter simply wrote: "Christ."
Elsewhere, Chris Kavanagh will referee Arsenal's clash against Brighton on Saturday lunchtime. Meanwhile, Jarred Gillett will take charge of Chelsea's match against Crystal Palace.

Gillett served as VAR for Fulham's win over Leicester, during which he controversially awarded Wout Faes' goal despite Jamie Vardy appearing to be offside. And fresh from the controversy at Bournemouth's draw against Newcastle, both David Coote and Tim Robinson have been handed appointments.

Coote served as referee at the Vitality Stadium, with Robinson the VAR. Three minutes into injury time, Bournemouth thought they had scored, but Robinson ruled it out for a highly-contensious handball.

Coote did not review the decision on the pitchside screen, with many fans left in disbelief. He will serve as referee for Aston Villa's trip to Leicester, while Robinson will be fourth official for Ipswich's game against Fulham.

headline: Chelsea's reason for pulling out of Manuel Ugarte transfer sparks concern for Man Utd
body: Manuel Ugarte looks set to join Manchester United from Paris Saint-Germain, but the Uruguayan was close to signing for Chelsea one year previously
Manchester United may be concerned by Chelsea's decision to pull out of signing Manuel Ugarte 12 months ago.

The Uruguayan is understood to be travelling to Old Trafford for a medical ahead of a seismic move from Paris Saint-Germain, which is believed to be worth around £51million. His arrival will take Erik ten Hag's side's spending for this summer to around £180m, with the Dutch boss having already signed Matthijs de Ligt, Noussair Mazraoui, Leny Yoro and Joshua Zirkzee.

Ugarte, 23, could have been playing in blue this season, as the west Londoners were keen on bringing him to Stamford Bridge during the early days of Mauricio Pochettino's reign. It was understood that Chelsea agreed to pay the £51m release clause his former club Sporting Lisbon placed on him. However, PSG trumped the  Blues by offering a higher bid that Chelsea believed did not match Ugarte's qualities, causing the Blues to pull out of the race for his signature.

Portuguese outlet Record, via football.london, also claimed that Chelsea offered him around £1.7m in wages per year. PSG reportedly offered him £4.3m per season, before suddenly deciding to double their offer to £8.6m. It was claimed at the time by Fabrizio Romano that Pochettino didn't want to risk putting Ugarte on a pedestal at Stamford Bridge and potentially upsetting other first-team players by agreeing to inflated wages.

Chelsea opted not to match those sort of numbers and duly turned their attentions elsewhere. Instead, the Blues decided to shatter the Premier League transfer record to sign Moises Caicedo for £115m, before splashing out a further £53m to bring Romeo Lavia to the Bridge from Brighton & Hove Albion.

Ironically, the Blues spent even more money on their new midfield duo. Their decision suggests they had considerably more confidence in the ex-Southampton and Brighton & Hove Albion stars than the Uruguayan, which doesn't necessarily bode well for United given Chelsea's travails last season and the context of their other failed transfer incomings in the Todd Boehly era so far.

Nevertheless, Ugarte arrives on the red side of Manchester with an impressive recent reputation. While his time with Luis Enrique in the French capital was not always perfect, Ugarte showed his quality in the recent Copa America.
He played in every match for Uruguay, who went on to finish third by overcoming Canada in a penalty shootout. Ugarte's arrival is also expected to open the door for Scott McTominay to leave.

The United academy prospect is set to seal an exciting move to Napoli, who are now managed by former Tottenham and Chelsea boss Antonio Conte. He will move to Italy for a fee expected to be around £25m.

At present, Ten Hag will have the likes of Kobbie Mainoo, Casemiro, and Christian Eriksen to choose from as well as Ugarte, while young prospects Toby Collyer and Daniel Gore may also be called upon by the Dutchman. The Red Devils have started the new campaign with a narrow 1-0 victory over Fulham and a dramatic, last-minute 2-1 defeat to Brighton and Hove Albion.
It's unclear as to whether Ugarte could be available for selection by the time United host Liverpool in their next Premier League match at Old Trafford.

headline: 5 bombshells in Jadon Sancho transfer saga as Chelsea and Man Utd consider swap deal
body: Jadon Sancho's dramatic time at Manchester United could be up as rumours of dramatic swap deal with Chelsea star Raheem Sterling swirl in the final days of the transfer window
Jadon Sancho's Manchester United nightmare could be coming to an end as rumours swirl he's off to Chelsea - with Raheem Sterling potentially going the other way.

The former Manchester City youth player's move to Borussia Dortmund saw him catch the eye of Europe's biggest clubs following a run of remarkable performances for the Black and Yellows. United eventually won the race for the winger, bringing him to Old Trafford for £72.9million in July 2021, and Sancho's blockbuster move looked to be the next big step for the youngster.

Since then however, Sancho's time at United has been beset by poor form, injury and a very public falling out with United manager Erik ten Hag. So, as Chelsea and United reportedly thrash out one of the biggest deals of the summer, Mirror Sport takes a look at just what went wrong for Jadon Sancho at Manchester United.

One of the driving forces behind Sancho's looming exit from United is his frosty relationship with Erik Ten Hag. Despite early promise between the two, with Sancho starring in the Dutchman's first pre-season with the club, Sancho's form began to dip, and an appearance against Chelsea in October 2022 proved to be his last in a United shirt for three months.

Ten Hag was reportedly concerned with Sancho's form and, after being omitted from England's 2022 World Cup squad, the winger was packed off to train in the Netherlands while his team-mates enjoyed a warm-weather camp in Spain. It was during this time that Ten Hag claimed Sancho needed to work on "a combination of physical but also mental” issues.

The start of the 2023/24 campaign yielded some success for Sancho with the player making substitute appearances in United's first three Premier League games. He was then left out of a squad to face Arsenal and Ten Hag, once again, cited poor performances in training as the primary reason for his absence.

Ten Hag said: "Jadon, on his performance in training, was not selected. You have to reach a level at Manchester United every day." This then led to the biggest bombshell of all between the two - a sensational Twitter post by Sancho in which the player pleaded with fans to not "believe everything you read".

The post went on to insinuate that Ten Hag was being dishonest and claimed he was being made a "scapegoat". In the wake of the tweet, the duo attempted to hash out their differences and are believed to have met up to clear the air.  While Sancho did eventually delete his inflammatory post, he allegedly refused to apologise to Ten Hag. On September 14th, United then released a statement saying that the player will “remain on a personal training programme away from the first-team group, pending resolution of a squad discipline issue”.

After Ten Hag and Sancho's breakdown in relations, it was even reported that United's manager had taken things one step further by kicking the player out of United's WhatsApp group. The group was apparently run by staff to inform the first team of any updates and Sancho was said to be unhappy with the decision.
United sources also confirmed the situation between the 24-year-old and Ten Hag has reached an "impasse", with no way back for the player until he decided to apologise for his social media post.

With Sancho not having featured for United since September 2023 following his spat with Ten Hag, he saw the January transfer window as a prime opportunity to reignite his career elsewhere. He rejoined his former club, Borussia Dortmund, on loan, on January 11th of this year.

The Germans reportedly paid a €4 million (£3.3million) loan fee to bring Sancho back to the Signal Iduna Park, and the switch proved to be a catalyst for the winger to rediscover his best form. “When I came into the dressing room today, it felt like ‘coming home’,” Sancho said after re-joining the German giants.

His performances certainly mirrored his statement as he helped Dortmund climb the Bundesliga table, and most notably, assisted his side's unlikely Champions League charge that saw them reach the final at Wembley. Stellar performances in the competition's quarter and semi-finals against Atletico Madrid and PSG respectively looked like Sancho had become the player of old, and he even sent a damming message to the 'non-believers' following the win in Paris.

Despite losing to Real Madrid in the final, Sancho was in a reflective mood after claiming on social media that he was "grateful" to be part of "an amazing group of players". In the same post he said that he felt like he was amongst "family" at BVB.

Sancho managed three goals and three assists in his 21 appearances for the Black and Yellows. It was understood that Dortmund wanted to bring the player back to the club on a permanent basis but United's steep asking price, believed to be in the range of £50million, meant they had to reconsider their options.
As recently as July, Ten Hag seemed to hint that Sancho had a future with United. Reports stated that the star had buried the hatchet with his manager and would be reintroduced to the United set-up.

However the saga took a strange twist once more. Speaking publicly for the first time since the pair apparently patched things up, Ten Hag claimed that their bad blood had simmered, yet he remained tight-lipped and evasive when asked if Sancho had a future at the club.
“As we said, we've drawn the line,” said Ten Hag. “Manchester United needs good players and Jadon is a good player. We have drawn that line and we move on.”

Just over two weeks into the new campaign Sancho has just played seven minutes under Ten Hag, which came in a substitute appearance in their Community Shield victory over Manchester City. The new dawn for Sancho looks to have set early and he now finds himself on the brink of a move away from Old Trafford once again.

Sancho isn't the only winger at a top Premier League club to find himself in limbo. Raheem Sterling has been the talk of the town since being frozen out of the Chelsea set-up under their new manager, Enzo Maresca.

A stunning deal to take Sancho to Chelsea, and Sterling to United, is now reportedly being discussed. Despite the transfer deadline looming, The Telegraph have reported that Sancho is one of several players the Blues are looking at this week but a swap between the pair appears to be an extremely complex deal to get over the line.

If a move to Stamford Bridge doesn't materialise it looks like Sancho could be on his way to Italy, with Serie A giant Juventus also taking a keen interest in Sancho's situation. Regardless of where the Sancho ends up come Friday at 11pm he will be hoping it's at a club where he can once again let his football do the talking.

headline: Ian Wright claims Man Utd star was 'laughing' at Erik ten Hag after strange decision
body: Two poor moments of defending left Erik ten Hag's Manchester United ruing missed opportunities as they suffered a 2-1 defeat to Brighton on the weekend
Ian Wright shared in Bruno Fernandes’ bemusement when Erik ten Hag substituted the midfielder in Manchester United's defeat to Brighton.
The Red Devils failed to carry on their good form from the Premier League’s opening day courtesy of a late collapse against the Seagulls.
Momentum was with Ten Hag’s side after Amad Diallo’s deflected strike cancelled out Danny Welbeck’s first-half goal.
But a lapse in defending, coupled with VAR misfortune, saw United slip to a 2-1 defeat in injury time Joao Pedro headed home the winner.
Ten Hag caught plenty of flak for the result, which was the latest example of United succumbing to late pressure under the Dutchman.
Wright was one such critic to admit he was confused by “a lot of things” in United’s display, not least the decision to remove Fernandes from the fold in the final stages.
United’s captain was replaced with just over 10 minutes to play and replaced by Scott McTominay, who has been linked with a permanent move away to Napoli before the end of the transfer window.
And the ex-England and Arsenal striker believes that Fernandes was confounded by the decision and was “laughing” as he made his way off the pitch.
“A lot of things happened in that game that I just couldn’t understand or see happening,” he said on the Wrighty’s House podcast.
“Like I can’t understand why he took Bruno off and went so defensive. Why are you taking him off?

“When he [Fernandes] ran off, he was actually smiling and laughing. He was like, ‘what the f***? I can’t believe this guy.’ That’s the vibe I got from it. If anyone is going to win a game for you it’s Bruno Fernandes.”
It’s the latest scrutiny to afflict Ten Hag, who has come under increasing pressure after two years at the helm despite achieving silverware in each term.

Last season saw United slump to their worst-ever finish in the Premier League era. Ten Hag narrowly avoided the sack this summer, with new minority ownership led by Sir Jim Ratcliffe having sounded out alternative managers–including Thomas Tuchel, Kieran McKenna and Thomas Frank–before opting to remain with Ten Hag.
United’s next Premier League opponents Liverpool have taken six points from their opening two games under new manager Arne Slot, beating Ipswich Town and Brentford ahead of the trip to Old Trafford.

headline: Man Utd's six Premier League injury time collapses under Erik ten Hag as alarming stat emerges
body: Manchester United fell to yet another late defeat at the weekend after Joao Pedro’s stoppage time winner for Brighton in a game that continued a worrying trend for the Red Devils
Erik ten Hag has been unable to break a worrying trend at Manchester United - and it continued against Brighton.
The Red Devils fell to a late 2-1 defeat to the Seagulls on Saturday. Danny Welbeck and Amad Diallo had exchanged strikes at the Amex Stadium before Joao Pedro headed home a stoppage-time winner.

It was the sixth time in the Premier League that United had lost a game in the closing moments under Ten Hag. In contrast, they only conceded two winning goals after the 90th minute before the Dutchman took control at Old Trafford.
That includes stints under Sir Alex Ferguson, David Moyes, Louis van Gaal, Jose Mourinho and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. Here we, take a look at all of the recent collapses over recent seasons.

It took a few months for the Red Devils to concede their first stoppage-time winner under Ten Hag but it proved to be a painful one. Travelling to the Emirates 18 months ago, United got off to the perfect start with Marcus Rashford’s opening goal.
But they weren’t ahead for very long as Eddie Nketiah levelled before Bukayo Saka put the Gunners ahead after the break. Ten Hag’s side thought they had stolen a point through Lisandro Martinez.
But the Emirates launched into wild celebrations as Nketiah doubled his evening’s work to condemn United to a late defeat.
Saturday’s reverse was not the first time that the Red Devils have suffered heartbreak in Sussex. The Red Devils slumped to an extraordinary defeat to Brighton at the end of Ten Hag’s first season.
United travelled south with ambitions of reaching the Champions League but they were left smarting. They were dominated throughout large swaths of the game but looked to have escaped with a point.
That was until Luke Shaw’s handball was penalised following a VAR review. Now Liverpool star Alexis Mac Allister stepped up in the 99th minute to slot past David de Gea.
Just a few months after Nketiah’s winner, the Red Devils were to face more Emirates frustration. And it was a familiar story.

Rashford opened the scoring midway through the first half but that lead did not last particularly long as Granit Xhaka equalised for Mikel Arteta’s side. United thought they had secured victory as Alejandro Garnacho scored but his strike was ruled out due to a marginal offside decision.

And Arsenal took advantage of the Red Devils' disgust to score twice in stoppage time. Declan Rice’s deflected shot found the net in the 96th minute before Gabriel Jesus put the result beyond doubt in the 101st minute of the game.

While the Red Devils’ heartbreak had so far been restricted to their away trips, Fulham managed to silence Old Trafford earlier this year. Defender Calvin Bassey had given Marco Silva’s side the lead after lashing home.
But fellow centre-back Harry Maguire appeared to steal a point for United with his equaliser. It was not meant to be though.
Former Arsenal forward Alex Iwobi got on the end of Adama Traore’s clever pass right at the death and coolly finished beyond Andre Onana.

The Red Devils did not have to wait long for another sobering reality check but this time, it was one of the most entertaining games in Premier League history. With their European hopes hanging by a thread, United practically had to win at Stamford Bridge.

Conor Gallagher got Chelsea off to the perfect start before Cole Palmer doubled the lead from the penalty spot. A horrendous error from Moises Caicedo saw Garnacho reduce the arrears, with Bruno Fernandes heading home an equaliser.

Ten Hag’s side completed a stunning turnaround as Garnacho scored his brace but it was Chelsea celebrating come the final whistle. Palmer’s stoppage time penalty looked to have snatched a point for the Blues.
But they were not done there as his deflected effort late on saw him secure the matchball and Chelsea bag the three points.
The Red Devils’ most recent collapse - and the inspiration behind this list. Ten Hag’s side turned in a distinctly average performance in their most recent outing.

They found themselves deservedly behind after former striker Welbeck opened the scoring with his 100th club career goal. Amad equalised for United with an effort that deflected in off of Jan Paul van Hecke.

A Garnacho strike was chalked off by Joshua Zirkzee's offside knee and somehow, United contrived to lose again. Joao Pedro was given the freedom of the penalty area to secure his side a memorable victory.

headline: Manuel Ugarte transfer set to be completed as Manchester United finally land their man
body: The Paris Saint-Germain midfielder is on his way to Manchester to complete a medical after the two clubs finally agreed a fee to bring the Uruguay international to the Premier League
Manchester United are closing on the signing of Manuel Ugarte after finally agreeing a fee with Paris Saint-Germain.
The Uruguay midfielder is en route to Manchester to undergo a medical, after agreeing terms with PSG for the 23-year-old's signature.
Ugarte is set to join United for an initial £42million, with a further £9million in add-ons. A formal agreement was reached between the two sides on Monday night.
Ugarte has been United's No.1 choice to add to their midfield this summer as they look for a long-term replacement for veteran anchorman Casemiro.

Sofyan Amrabat failed to impress while on loan from Fiorentina last season, and while Kobbie Mainoo has broken through into the first-team, Erik ten Hag has been desperate to add another layer of defensive protection into the heart of his side.

And while Ugarte struggled to make an impact in his debut season at PSG - having joined for £51million from Sporting Lisbon last summer - he has been United's top target, having again impressed club officials with his performances for Marcelo Bielsa's Uruguay at this summer's Copa America.

And although it's fair to say Ugarte struggled with the demands of life at the Parc des Princes last term, he still made 37 appearances for Luis Enrique's side, contributing to their Ligue 1 title, Coupe de France and Trophee des Champions triumphs.
He is now set to become United's fifth signing of the summer, after the arrivals of Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt, Joshua Zirkzee and Noussair Mazraoui.
His arrival will further hasten the departure of Scotland international Scott McTominay, who is set to join Antonio Conte's Napoli in a £30million deal.

headline: Sven-Goran Eriksson's true thoughts on Wayne Rooney speak volumes about man he was
body: Sven-Goran Eriksson was the first manager to bring Wayne Rooney into the fold and his honest thoughts about the Manchester United legend summed him up as a human being
The late Sven-Goran Eriksson did everything he could to defend Wayne Rooney when he was in charge of England.

Eriksson passed away at the age of 76 after a battle with pancreatic cancer. Rooney, who is now the manager of Plymouth Argyle, was one of the first of his former players to issue a heartfelt tribute to the Swede.

The former Three Lions boss was the first manager to take a chance on the Manchester United legend, deploying him at Euro 2004 when he was just a teenager and the 2006 World Cup, despite suffering a metatarsal fracture on the eve of the tournament in Germany. Rooney was also sent off in the World Cup quarter-final against Portugal, which went on to cost the Three Lions a place in the semi-final.
But while being knocked out by the Portuguese for a second consecutive major competition went on to be Eriksson's final game in the job, the Swede immediately looked to defend the young striker.

When the red mist descended on Rooney after he trod on Ricardo Carvalho's crutch, Eriksson remembered the public vitriol David Beckham experienced when he was sent off in a similar manner in the 1998 World Cup. He recalled the national hatred which greeted Beckham when he returned to the country.

Determined to ensure Rooney would not receive such a welcome, Eriksson did his best to shield Rooney from similar treatment. In his final press conference as manager, Eriksson said: "You, more than me, need Wayne Rooney in the next few years so, please, pay attention.
“Don't kill him, I beg you. Whether he did it intentionally or not, leave it. Take it easy with Rooney, for your own sake.
“You need him, so take care of him. You will need him in qualifying for Euro 2008 and you will need him to win it.
“He is the golden boy of English football. So, please, make it easier for him to come back than it was for Beckham. I have no hard feelings with him. None at all and nor should you."

Rooney tweeted his condolences and sadness about Eriksson's death. The 38-year-old said: "Rest in peace, Sven. A special man. Thanks for the memories and all your help and advice. Thoughts and prayers with all his family and friends."

Soon after his death, Eriksson's son and daughter Johan and Lina released a statement which said: “Dad told us at the beginning of this year about his serious illness and received an amazing response from friends and football fans around Europe. He was invited to several football teams in England, Italy, Portugal and Sweden.

"They shared their love for football and for dad. It was unforgettable for both him and us. He expressed his appreciation and joy and stated that such beautiful words are usually only uttered when someone has died.

"We have shared his gratitude and got to experience the wonderful meetings between him, football and all his friends. We thank everyone for these positive memories and your support during his illness. We hope that you will remember Svennis as the good and positive person he always was both in public and at home with us.”

headline: Raheem Sterling to make Chelsea squirm over transfer ahead of Friday's deadline
body: Raheem Sterling appears to have little Chelsea future under Enzo Maresca and his thoughts on an exit have been revealed just days before the summer transfer window finally closes
Raheem Sterling will only leave Chelsea on HIS terms after being told he has no future at the club.

The former Manchester City winger is out of favour with new boss Enzo Maresca. After leaving him out of his first squad against the reigning champions, the Italian revealed it would be better for Sterling to look for opportunities elsewhere.

The winger’s camp also released a statement demanding clarity from the Blues, particularly given the role he had played in pre-season, while he also had his squad number given to summer arrival Pedro Neto. Sterling has already been linked with a number of moves - Juventus and Aston Villa among those to have been offered the chance to sign him.
Manchester United have emerged as an option with a potential swap deal involving Jadon Sancho under consideration. But it appears that Sterling will have the final decision over his future.

The 29-year-old’s preference is to stay in the Premier League but it remains to be seen whether Chelsea can thrash out a deal with one of their domestic rivals. Now, according to The Sun, he will also only move to a club that he is happy with and is not intending to lodge a transfer request to force a move away from Chelsea.

That would leave the club in a tricky position over the winger’s eye-watering contract. The club would need to agree a suitable severance package with their winger in order to get him off the books... or pay him big, in accordance with his contract.

Chelsea’s sporting directors Paul Winstanley and Laurence Stewart will lead talks with Sterling in an effort to come to an agreeable conclusion. But should that not occur, that would leave them in an extremely tricky position of having to pay Sterling’s lofty wages while out of favour.

There is also a significant race against time with the summer transfer window set to slam shut on Friday evening. Sterling still has three years left on his current deal, while the next opportunity he would have to move to another Premier League club would be January.
Sterling was signed in a £47m deal from Man City two years ago. He has made 81 appearances in all competitions since then and has scored 19 goals.

Speaking about the ongoing situation last week, Maresca said: "I spoke with Raheem, one-on-one the day before City and I explained him exactly the situation. I don’t see Raheem after the game. He is training apart as I said, but in case I sit with Raheem, I will tell him exactly the same things that I already told him. I don’t have anything new to tell him because I was quite clear."

headline: Victor Osimhen to Arsenal, Ivan Toney to Man Utd - Late transfer window moves predicted
body: THE BIG DEBATE: We're into the final few days of the transfer window, so what bold predictions do our team have for moves that we could be seeing?
The transfer window will soon be s̶l̶a̶m̶m̶i̶n̶g̶ s̶h̶u̶t̶ closing, but there's still plenty of time for a few deals to be wrapped up in the final few days before Big Ben goes bong.

Manchester United are still set to be active in their pursuit of yet more midfield and attacking reinforcements, while Arsenal have been looking at wide players and Liverpool... well... Liverpool are yet to do anything at all really.
So how will the final days of the window shape up then? We asked our Mirror Football team to make some bold predictions for what we could be about to see.

Victor Osimhen will sign for Arsenal. There’s been a very simple reason why the Gunners have not won the Premier League the past two seasons - they haven’t had that 20-goal striker. And now there’s one ready and waiting for them.

Osimhen has already made clear his desire to leave Napoli and talk from Italy suggests that both Chelsea and Arsenal are going head to head for his signature. The Blues could have an advantage given Romelu Lukaku’s impending move to Naples, but it has been suggested that they have already baulked at Osimhen’s lofty wage demands and are looking for alternatives.

That could potentially give Arsenal the perfect opportunity to strike. Sure, any deal for the Nigerian will cost in excess of £100m. But that will represent an absolute bargain should his goals carry Arsenal to the title.
Napoli will also be receiving an incredible amount for a player angling to leave, who has already helped them to silverware. If anything, this one makes too much sense.

Everyone celebrates the end of a transfer window - because it means Sky Sports can put away that daft countdown clock, as if our lives all depend on whether Huddersfield Town are going to sign a fat left-back from Spain you've never heard of anyway.
To date, and despite Chelsea's latest bout of ostentatious muscle-flexing, Premier League spending is £800 million down on the corresponding window last summer.

But there's still time to offend the hard-up who can't afford their fuel bills, or the climate police by filling the skies with private jets where a perfectly reasonable alternative exists on a scheduled airline, so here goes...
Victor Osimhen from Napoli to Chelsea - if the Blues can get rid of £80 million of excess ballast in that ridiculous 42-man squad.
Giorgi Mamardashvili from Valencia to Liverpool , finally handing Arne Slot his first signing at Anfield in a position where he's already well-covered.
And Mikel Merino to complete his £30 million move from Real Sociedad to Arsenal , which has been signposted more than London on the M1.
Then we can all pour ourselves a large one and Manchester City win the title as usual (subject to 115 large ones).
Perhaps this is the one that should happen, rather than will, but Manchester United still need a goalscorer and Ivan Toney still needs a move . It just makes too much sense.

Brentford are resigned to losing the forward, having left him out of both of their Premier League matchday squads. United meanwhile look resigned to the fact they don't have a natural goalscorer. Watching their forward players toil against Brighton, it was painfully obvious what they were lacking.

Even with Rasmus Hojlund they don't have a player capable of scoring 20-plus goals. A focal point like Toney would provide them with the kind of cutting edge so desperately needed. If United are seriously backing Erik ten Hag, then another striker is needed and as the hours of the window tick down, a desperate move for Toney should be on the cards.
If Aaron Ramsdale has designs on a serious international career, he needs to get himself out of Arsenal by the end of this week .

It looked like Ramsdale would be the Gunners' No.1 for the foreseeable future before Mikel Arteta made the decision to swoop for Brentford goalkeeper David Raya. And you cannot say that decision hasn't been justified. Which leaves Ramsdale in a tricky spot.

Wolves have been linked with a move for his services, and it's a switch that makes sense in a whole manner of ways. Jose Sa continues to polarise opinion in the Black Country, and shipping six goals against Chelsea on Sunday hasn't helped his cause.
Ramsdale hails from neighbouring Staffordshire and first-team opportunities at a club lower down the Premier League shouldn't harm his chances with England, as Jordan Pickford has shown.

So Liverpool are signing definitely signing one player in Giorgi Mamardashvili, just one that won't be around until next season. Or maybe even the one after that. The lack of transfer activity at Anfield is understandable as a new manager seeks to get to know his squad but surely one or two come in for the here and now before the deadline?

There is interest in the Italian winger Federico Chiesa who might end up joining, and I've got a feeling the Portuguese defender Goncalo Inacio will do too, swelling Arne Slot's squad before Friday's deadline. He's young, he's a left-sided centre-back and he can cover at left-back as well. He'd be a decent addition to a squad which has started well.

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson's faultless transfer policy that Man Utd have now abandoned
body: Despite attaining almost unrivalled success as a Premier League manager, Sir Alex Ferguson kept things relatively simple when it came to one tradition in the transfer market
The modern day Manchester United would do well to take inspiration from one of Sir Alex Ferguson 's transfer policies: sign the best player in the Premier League.

Or at least the Scot would always make an attempt to recruit the player he felt was the standard-bearer of England's top flight at the time. That's according to Gary Neville, who lifted the lid on his old boss' tradition - which paid off more often than not.

United's transfer portfolio is of more interest than ever before as the club looks to return to the glory days of old. However, the club would likely struggle to succeed in the same vein that Ferguson once did given the club no longer boasts the same pulling power as when he was in charge.

"There was a philosophy, I think, of buying. He wanted to bring young players through, and he wanted the best player in the Premier League," said Neville on a recent episode of The Overlap. "I think if you had the best British player in the Premier League, he had to buy.

"Manchester United had to buy that player, and I think that's why they always had to. . .they broke transfer records for [Roy] Keane, they broke transfer records for [Wayne] Rooney, they tried to sign [Alan] Shearer, tried to sign [Paul] Gascoigne.

"So if you think about what he tried to do, he had a clear philosophy every single year. Even [Robin] van Persie, even though he wasn't British, he tried to sign the best Premier League player - and more often than not, they were British back then, but obviously now they're foreign players."

It's a straightforward scheme, though perhaps one that wouldn't be as easy to pull off today as it was 20 or more years ago. And Erik ten Hag may struggle to convince certain stars from Manchester City, Arsenal or Liverpool that their silverware hopes were better served at Old Trafford in the current climate.

United may have won the FA Cup last season, though the club is still coming off the back off an eighth-place league finish, their worst of the Premier League era. And despite some very promising transfer signings this summer, Saturday's 2-1 defeat at Brighton was the latest reminder there's work to be done.

With less than a week of the summer transfer window remaining, Ten Hag is in a race against time to conduct any more business that would greatly improve his squad. That being said, forefather Ferguson found the best solutions to improving his own team was often the most simple.

headline: 15 players desperately needing a transfer THIS WEEK - and where they might end up
body: Manchester United, Arsenal and Chelsea could be among the sides looking to sell players during the final week of the 2024 summer transfer window as frantic business is set to be completed
There’s now just a matter of days remaining of the 2024 summer transfer window and we’re into panic territory now.

Clubs in the Premier League and beyond are scrambling around for any late deals they can do. Some will invariably be sucked into overspending on panic buys, while others could surprise with some eye-catching deals.

It’s not just directors of football and managers desperately working hard for any last minute deals. Players will also be nervously waiting by the phone - whether they’re awaiting confirmation of that dream move, or they’re desperate to escape their current employers.

While transfer windows all over Europe will close at different times, the race is on. With that being said, take a look at some players who will be hoping that they can put pen to paper on a switch over the coming days.
We start with the most obvious one. Raheem Sterling looks to have little future at Chelsea - and has been told practically that by Enzo Maresca.

He has no place in the squad and doesn’t even have a number. It’s just best for everyone if he leaves Stamford Bridge. Manchester United, Aston Villa and Juventus have all been linked but his huge wages might be a stumbling block.

Staying with Chelsea (we’ll do that quite a lot), Sterling’s Blues teammate and England colleague Ben Chilwell also needs to quit Stamford Bridge to revive his career. Maresca has also told the former Leicester defender that he does not fit into his plans.
Chilwell is still a more than capable fullback so a Premier League move would make the most sense. Manchester United have been touted as potential suitors in a swap deal involving Jadon Sancho.
Who should your Premier League club sign? Share your suggestions in the comments below

The final name in a Chelsea trio, Blues academy graduate Trevoh Chalobah has been banished from the club’s first-team facilities and also does not have a squad number. Should he decide to leave Stamford Bridge, he will not be short of suitors.

The 25-year-old is certainly at a crossroads but can look to the likes of Fikayo Tomori, Tammy Abraham and Ruben Loftus-Cheek for proof that there is life after Chelsea. Wolves, Newcastle and moves abroad have all been mooted.

While there is work to do at Chelsea to get their fringe players out, it already looks as though that is happening at Arsenal. Eddie Nketiah looked to be on the verge of a move away to Nottingham Forest but that deal has since collapsed.

There are others interested in him though - most notably Crystal Palace. Nketiah has largely played second string over the past couple of seasons so a fresh start might do the striker good in the long run.

From one English striker to another, Ivan Toney seems sure to leave Brentford this summer. The forward has just a year remaining on his contract - meaning the Bees are running out of chances to cash in on him.

Thomas Frank has admitted that Toney could potentially leave. But it remains a mystery over where he will be. Premier League interest appears to have faded, leaving Saudi Arabia as the striker’s most likely destination - unless Chelsea or Arsenal appear late in the day.

Sancho appears to be in a far better place than this time last year. The winger looked destined for the exit door after a very public falling out with Erik ten Hag and joined former club Borussia Dortmund months later.

Things have improved but that has not seen Sancho rewarded with opportunities. He was left out of the Red Devils’ side vs Brighton and has been linked with a move to Chelsea, who like him but know doing a deal could be difficult. Juventus are still in the mix.
The case of Joao Cancelo is one of the most baffling of recent seasons. The Portuguese defender was arguably the best fullback in the world during his peak.

But he was then sent out on loan to Bayern Munich, while Cancelo also joined Barcelona on a temporary deal last term. He appears to have little future at the Etihad so will be very keen to get away from Manchester once again over the coming days. A switch to Saudi Arabia has been mooted.

Scottish defender Kieran Tierney has been slightly unlucky during his time with Arsenal. Since joining the club from Celtic, he has been blighted by injuries and that has seen him drop down the pecking order.
In an effort to earn some more playing time, he joined Spanish side Real Sociedad on loan last season. He could choose to pursue another move away over the final few days of the window.

Sticking with players who sought out a loan move to Spain last season, goalkeeper Kepa Arrizabalaga joined Real Madrid last term. Still the world’s most expensive stopper, his chances of first-team football appear very slim now he is back with Chelsea.

Robert Sanchez is still the club’s number one, while Chelsea have signed Filip Jorgensen from Villarreal. Fortunately, Kepa already appears to have lined up a loan move to Bournemouth so will at least be playing some football this season.
It’s a slight surprise that Scottish winger Fraser has not left Newcastle already. The 30-year-old spent last season on loan with Southampton.

After scoring eight goals during the Saints’ promotion push, they remain keen to sign him permanently. As it stands, that has not happened. If it doesn’t, any chances of first-team football at St James' Park seem remote at best.

It’s fair to say that Neal Maupay has endured an absolute nightmare time of things with Everton. After signing for £15m from Brighton two years ago, the French striker has scored just a solitary goal.

The Toffees were happy to let him return to his former club Brentford on loan last term. His relationship with supporters is only more strained now after he criticised abusive fans for their angry tirade following a 4-0 defeat to Tottenham. Can they find a buyer?

While Maupay has really struggled to find the net with his current club, the same can certainly not be said of Nigerian hitman Victor Osimhen. The 25-year-old has netted 76 goals in 133 appearances for the Italian giants.

But it looks as though he’s ready for the next stage of his career. He asked to leave earlier this summer amid interest from Chelsea and Arsenal. Saudi clubs are also attempting to tempt him to the Middle East, but he wants to remain in Europe. Chelsea still appear most likely.

Staying in Italy, it appears as though wideman Federico Chiesa will leave Juventus before the month is out. New Juve boss Thiago Motta has already suggested that he is not in his plans for the current season.

Barcelona look set to make a move for him but it will be easier said than done. The Catalans’ dire financial situation means that they are struggling to register players so a move for Chiesa will not be straightforward and he may be forced to look elsewhere.

Chiesa’s former Juventus teammate Adrien Rabiot is also on the lookout for a new club but there isn’t too much of a rush. The Frenchman left Juventus at the end of his contract with his contract expiring.

He has regularly been linked with moves to Liverpool and Manchester United. He will still be able to sign for a new club after the end of the transfer window but will be keen to get a deal over the line sooner rather than later.
Once Barcelona’s gem in their academy, Ansu Fati’s career has stuttered over recent seasons. He joined Brighton last season and scored four goals across what was an inconsistent campaign.

New Barcelona boss Hansi Flick has hinted that he would be happy to keep Fati around. But the forward might hope for an opportunity elsewhere should he not feature in the German’s plans for the season.

headline: Rio Ferdinand admits Manchester United transfer decision 'does not sit well with me'
body: Rio Ferdinand has called Manchester United's summer transfer strategy into question after the Red Devils agreed to sell a player who had been key in Erik ten Hag's first two seasons
Rio Ferdinand has questioned Manchester United's decision to sell Scott McTominay to Napoli.

The midfielder is set to move to the Serie A side in a £25million deal, though personal terms still need to be agreed. Since graduating from United's academy, McTominay has become a regular fixture in their first-team.

In total, the 27-year-old has made 255 appearances in all competitions for the Red Devils. But he has fallen down the pecking order under Erik ten Hag, with the Dutchman pursuing a move for another midfielder in PSG star Manuel Ugarte.

Despite that Ferdinand has been left stunned at the decision to let McTominay leave. He warned United boss Ten Hag that he is making a mistake in forcing out the Scot, even though he is not in his plans.

"I look at Scott McTominay and not every player can be a star, a standout player. But to win the league you need the likes of John O’Shea, Wes Brown, Darren Fletcher… you need a Julian Alvarez at Man City," Ferdinand told Vibe with Five.

"They might not start every game but they were huge, you need those players and most of them know the DNA of the club, especially ones who have come through the academy, there’s a lot to be said for that.

"It really doesn’t sit well with me. To replace him you’re going to have to spend £30m or £40m and give him £150,000 a week probably. It’s not going to be cheap and it’s a gamble, you don’t know what you’re going to get.
"Whereas with McTominay you know what you’re getting. He might not always be a 9/10 but invariably he’s a solid 7/10 and sometimes he will be an 8/10 and get you a goal."

McTominay still has a year to run on his contract at United, but selling him would represent 'pure profit' when it comes to the Premier League's financial rules. Napoli sporting director Giovanni Manna has held extensive talks with United over a move for the midfielder.

Earlier this summer, United rejcted a £20m bid from Fulham, who moved on to other targets. The decision to sell McTominay represents something of a U-turn, after Ten Hag claimed he wanted the Scot to remain at the club.

“We have very good players so there will always be an interest from other clubs. When you score 10 goals in a season and also perform very good for Scotland, then there will be an interest," the Dutchman said in July.

"But we want to keep him because he is a very important player for our squad. What he can contribute, as we saw last season once we had our sixes available, he could play in a more advanced role and he is a highly interesting player for our team.”

headline: David Beckham reveals last four words Sven-Goran Eriksson told him at final meetingVIDEO
body: The former England captain, who led his country throughout Sven-Goran Eriksson's spell as manager of the national team, recently visited the Swede at his home for a final meeting before his death was announced on Monday
When David Beckham travelled to Sweden to meet Sven-Goran Eriksson this summer, the pair knew it would be the final time.

The former England captain has spoken to his former Three Lions boss and understood that time was short for the 76-year-old, who revealed in January that he was fighting against pancreatic cancer. On Monday, the Swede, who led England for five years, overseeing two World Cups - reaching the quarter-finals on both occasions - and Euro 2024 - another last eight appearance - and that 5-1 win in Germany in 2001, passed away.
But in his final meeting with his former skipper, Eriksson told the former Manchester United and England superstar: "It will be OK."

Eriksson revealed in January that he had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and had been told he had “best case” a year to live. That led to an outpouring of love and support across the globe, while Eriksson was given the opportunity to manage his beloved Liverpool in a charity match at Anfield in March.

Eriksson admitted he had shed tears before and after the Liverpool ‘Legends’ match, and said: “To sit on the bench for Liverpool, that’s been my dream my whole life. Now it happened, and it was a beautiful day in all meanings. It’s a good finish, to finish with Liverpool, it can’t be much better than that.”

As Eriksson's condition worsened, Beckham flew to Sweden to meet Sven at his home in Sunne, overlooking Lake Fryken, the place where Eriksson's ashes may now be scattered. They stood, they spoke, they walked, they cried, an increasingly fragile yet determined Sven at times needing to use Beckham to remain upright.
In a post shared on social media following the announcement of Sven's death on Monday, Beckham emotionally declared: "We laughed, we cried and we knew we were saying goodbye...

"Sven thank you for always being the person you have always been, passionate, caring, calm and a true gentleman. I will be forever grateful for you making me your captain but I will forever hold these last memories of this day with you and your family.
"Thank you Sven and in your last words to me: "It will be OK".

Italian lawyer Nancy Dell’Olio also paid tribute to her “ex-husband” on Instagram. The 63-year-old said: “It is with a heavy heart that I share the passing of my ex-husband, Sven. Though our relationship had its ups and downs, I choose to remember the good times we shared and the moments that brought joy to our lives.

“I will always hold onto those cherished memories and extend my deepest condolences to his family, as well as his beloved children, Lina and Johan. When you love someone, that love never truly fades. Rest in peace, Sven. You will be missed.”
Although they were in a relationship between 1998 and 2007, the pair had not previously been thought to have been married.

Wayne Rooney described Eriksson as a “special man” as he paid his tribute too. Taking to social media, Rooney wrote: “Rest in peace, Sven. A special man. Thanks for the memories and all your help and advice. Thoughts and prayers with all his family and friends.”

Rooney’s old England team-mate Michael Owen, who was the hat-trick hero in the 5-1 rout of Germany in Munich in 2001 - the highlight of Eriksson’s reign as manager - described the Swede as “one of the very best”.
“Rest In Peace Sven-Goran Eriksson. One of the very best and a man who will be sadly missed by everyone in the world of football,” Owen wrote.

Current England captain Harry Kane paid tribute to the Swede in a post on Instagram too. Kane said: “I didn’t have the privilege of playing under Sven but I know how well liked and respected he was by those who played under him as England manager. My thoughts are with his family and friends at this time.”

Former FA executive director David Davies paid his own tribute, saying on Sky Sports: “I think it was his charm, his politeness, his intelligence and his kindness, his immense kindness over many years. He was outwardly unflappable.”
Inter Milan manager Simone Inzaghi thanked Eriksson for the influence he had on his career when he played under the Swede at Lazio, winning the Serie A title in 1999-2000 among other honours.

“The passing of Sven-Goran Eriksson is a great pain for me,” Inzaghi said on the Inter website. “He was fundamental in my growth as a footballer and as a man. I admired his calm, his education, the great respect he had for everyone.

“Sven was a great man, an example of life for everyone. These last months faced with great strength and a unique desire to live have been a further demonstration of his greatness: he taught us to live while he was dying.”
The FA have confirmed that tributes will be paid to Sven when England next play at Wembley, against Finland in the UEFA Nations League, on September 10.

headline: Erik ten Hag green lights transfer for Man Utd star involved in training ground fight
body: Erik ten Hag is willing to let midfielder Hannibal Mejbri depart Old Trafford for another Championship loan deal, with Burnley in need of replacing the departed Sander Berge, who has joined Fulham,
Manchester United have agreed a loan deal - with an obligation to buy - for Hannibal Mejbri to join recently-relegated Burnley.
The Tunisian international has been the subject of interest from Burnley and Championship rival Leeds United after he was deemed surplus to requirements by manager Erik ten Hag.

The midfielder joined the Red Devils from Monaco in 2019 in a deal worth a potential £9million. He went on to make 13 first-team appearances for the club, scoring once, having broken through the first team under former manager Ralf Rangnick.

Hannibal spent the 2022-23 campaign on loan with Birmingham City, before spending the second half of last term with Spanish side Sevilla. There, he played a total of six games, struggling to make a case for himself.

Now Ten Hag is offloading the midfielder, and Burnley – needing to replace Sander Berge who joined Fulham earlier this month– have leapt to the head of the queue with Mejbri undergoing a medical with the Clarets on Monday ahead of completing the move.
Mejbri, 21, previously made headlines when he let his temper get the better of him in 2022 during a training group scuffle.

After a humbling 4-0 loss to  Brighton, then-head coach Ralf Rangnick was forced to end a training session early after it was reported that Mejbri and teammate Alex Telles were involved in an altercation.

The two allegedly had to be pulled apart because the incident was so severe, but that didn't stop the young Tunisian from continuing to feature under Rangnick. Days later, he played in the club's final match of the season against  Crystal Palace .

The young midfielder is the latest player to leave United this summer, joining Facundo Pellistri, Maxi Oyedele, Will Fish, Raphael Varane, Anthony Martial, Donny van de Beek, Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Mason Greenwood, Omari Forson and Willy Kambwala as Ten Hag continues his revamp of the squad.

headline: Man Utd legend admits defeat on Marcus Rashford's decline - 'He just seems unhappy'
body: Marcus Rashford has endured another difficult start to a Premier League season and it appears one Manchester United legend does not have an explanation why
Manchester United legend Dwight Yorke has warned Marcus Rashford that only he can drag himself out of this slump.

The new Premier League season is only two games old, yet the former England international's form is already worrying United fans and ex-players. Rashford failed to have a shot on goal in the 1-0 victory over Fulham and the recent 2-1 away defeat by Brighton and Hove Albion.

This slow start precedes the last campaign, which saw him only contribute seven goals and three assists in 33 Premier League appearances for Erik ten Hag's side. Over this period, he has also been outshone by the likes of Alejandro Garnacho, who is still being left on the bench in place of Rashford.

Rashford was also left out of Gareth Southgate's England squad which reached the final of Euro 2024. With the 26-year-old disappointed to be snubbed by the Three Lions boss, Yorke admits he is surprised with Rashford's tepid start to the season.

Speaking to talkSPORT, Yorke said: "You have to find out where the individual is at, what is going through his head, what is his thought process in his everyday life. At the end of the day, we all have issues, we all have tough times in our lives.

"I am sure that being left out of the England set-up last year, you expect him to come back with a little bit of fire in his belly and kick on after a poor season by his standards. Marcus Rashford is the only person who can get himself out of that slump.
"You can bring in the best coaches around him, but he has to have that burning desire to get himself back. We know he has all the talent and all the ability.
"But if he is not prepared to put that effort in and really bring himself back from his poorest season last year, he is not going to get back to that level. He has to want to do it.
"I have defended Marcus many times, but he just seems unhappy. For whatever reason I don't know, but just does not seem to be enjoying his football like he used to.”

Rashford has the perfect opportunity to hit back at the critics when United host Liverpool at Old Trafford on Sunday, September 1. Arne Slot's side have enjoyed a flawless start to the new Premier League campaign and United will fall six points behind their fierce rivals if they are beaten at home by the Dutchman's team.

Rashford has been having "extra sessions" with United assistant manager and club legend Ruud van Nistelrooy. At present, it does not appear to be working, as Newcastle United legend Alan Shearer pointed out in blunt fashion on Match of the Day.

The ex-England captain said: "Ruud van Nistelrooy's been brought into there and he's going to have to work his magic somehow. I know they have got [Rasmus] Hojlund out injured but when he comes in he's going to have to improve that because, on today's evidence and in the game against Fulham, it's not been anywhere near good enough."
When asked about Rashford, he also added: "He's not a youngster anymore. He has to understand the position and look across the pitch when you can see the whole of it, you shouldn't be offside then."
