headline: Man Utd have major Raheem Sterling advantage in Jadon Sancho swap deal with Chelsea
body: Raheem Sterling could make the move to Manchester United this summer - with Enzo Maresca making his stance on the England legend clear as the 2024/25 Premier League campaign unfurls
Raheem Sterling has already made his thoughts on Manchester United clear as a potential transfer to Old Trafford looms.

The 29-year-old has been dropped by new Chelsea boss Enzo Maresca as the 2024/25 campaign kicks off, failing to even make it as far as the bench for the west London side's games against Manchester City and Wolves. On top of this, the Italian has stripped Sterling of his patented No 7 and has sent him away from training with the first team.

And while Sterling's current club are open to offers for the forward - who still has years left in him - nothing has come to fruition as of yet. Maresca has welcomed a wealth of signings to Stamford Bridge this summer, including marquee signings like Pedro Neto and Joao Felix, but he could have more work to be done ahead of Friday's deadline.

One deal that Maresca is reportedly considering is a swap deal which would see Sterling head back to Manchester - albeit in a red shirt - in return for 24-year-old Jadon Sancho, who hasn't managed to break through under Erik ten Hag just yet. Sancho has also been omitted from his side's squads for their Premier League openers against Fulham and Brighton, after returning from a hit-and-miss loan spell with Borussia Dortmund.

Sancho featured in just 14 Bundesliga games for Die Schwarzgelben across the 2023/24 campaign, and with Marcus Rashford heavily in favour at Old Trafford, it looks unlikely that the left-winger will get any game time under Ten Hag. And should a deal come to light between Chelsea and Manchester United come to fruition before Friday, the Red Devils will certainly have an advantage going forward.

That's because Sterling has admitted that he was previously a Manchester United fan, speaking about how he used to don the famous red shirt in his younger years. Speaking to The Mirror in 2019, Sterling confessed: "I shouldn't really say this - not now, definitely not now! - but when I was young I was a massive United fan."

He added: "I had an old United kit, from when they won the last FA Cup. I was at the final in 2007." In a similar turn of events, it recently came to knowledge that Sancho was also a Chelsea fan when he was growing up - idolising the likes of Frank Lampard and Didier Drogba.

Speaking to talkSPORT back in 2019, the star said: "I was a Chelsea fan growing up, I can’t lie. Didier Drogba and Frank Lampard were my favourite players at the time." Sterling has had quite the fall from grace from his glory days at Manchester City.

The England international came up through the ranks of the Liverpool youth academy before making his professional debut for the first team in 2012. He went on to score 23 goals in 129 appearances on Merseyside before Pep Guardiola and City came a-knocking in 2015 with a deal rising to £49million.

Over the next seven years, Sterling scored 131 in 339 games for the Citizens, lifting four Premier League titles, five League Cups and an FA Cup and a Community Shield a-piece. Many fans questioned his shock move to Chelsea in 2022, but Sterling later revealed that he was unhappy in Manchester towards the end of his tenure.

Things have been far from smooth sailing with Chelsea however, being phased out of the side ahead of the new Premier League season by new boss Maresca, who has plenty of players to pick and choose from in attack. Cole Palmer, Christopher Nkunku and Noni Madueke have all found favour at Stamford Bridge thus far, as well as new boys Felix and Neto.

headline: Manchester United hold Raheem Sterling transfer talks with Chelsea

A possible swap involving England internationals Sancho and Sterling has been touted with United keen to sell the former while the latter was stripped of the number seven at Chelsea.
Well-placed sources say both parties will reassess the development of a potential deal ahead of Friday's transfer deadline.

Sancho earns around £250,000-a-week, which will have reduced following United's failure to qualify for the Champions League. Sterling is on a £325,000 weekly salary at Chelsea, which would leave United worse off under the Premier League's profitability and sustainability rules.

United have stressed they would only be prepared to do deals that would aid their profitability and sustainability calculations for next year. United also have two wingers on the right and left-hand sides, with Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount also options on the right.

Chelsea want to sell Sterling after he was left out of their opening game of the season against Manchester City. The winger's representatives published a statement before kick-off seeking "clarity" on his role and Sterling is now training away from the first team squad.
Sterling grew up supporting United and has remarkably never scored against them in 26 appearances for Liverpool, City and Chelsea.

United have no plans to move for Sterling's fellow Chelsea outcast, Ben Chilwell. Chelsea want to sell the left back and United are currently devoid of their senior left backs, Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia, due to injury.

Right back Diogo Dalot has started the season at left back and new signing Noussair Mazraoui is also able to play there. Seventeen-year-old left back Harry Amass was promoted to the first team squad after his impressive pre-season tour performances.
Shaw is expected to return from a calf injury next month while manager Erik ten Hag has suggested Malacia could recover from a knee problem that has caused him to miss the last 15 months in October.
United held discussions with Chelsea about a mooted loan move for left back Marc Cucurella last year after Shaw suffered a hamstring injury two games into the season.

"Jadon Sancho took a really risky move in many ways but almost an unavoidable one in going back to where he was to try to reignite that spark, and he's done particularly well," he told Prime Casino.
"I'm sure he probably would have preferred there to have been a change of manager at Old Trafford so it was a clean slate and he could come back and hopefully start again.
"I don't know what his future holds, but he's certainly gone away and proven that he can still cut it at the top level."
Transfer expert Gianluca Di Marzio has provided the latest on Manuel Ugarte.

"I think that Manuel Ugarte will go to Man Utd because he always wanted United. He agreed personal terms for a lot of days and I think that he will go to United. Man Utd are talking to Napoli to agree the final details of McTominay," he told bettingexpert.com

"The way is McTominay out and Ugarte in. The three clubs, PSG, Man Utd and Napoli are trying to do this linked deal. To get this deal done, McTominay has to solve his problems with United by agreeing exit terms.

"If he agrees to the exit terms, Napoli are ready to get him because they have already agreed a deal with United for about €30.5 million. If McTominay goes to Napoli, then Ugarte will be his replacement in Manchester."

headline: Manchester United agree £42.3m Manuel Ugarte deal as transfer approach explained
body: Manchester United have agreed a fee with Paris Saint-Germain to sign Manuel Ugarte, who is set to travel to Manchester today to undergo a medical ahead of his move to Old Trafford.

United have been pursuing the 23-year-old holding midfielder throughout the summer transfer window and after lengthy negotiations with PSG they have now agreed a fee of €50m (£42.3m), with a further €10m (£8.5m) in add-ons. Ugarte will now have his medical before signing a contract with United.

United had identified Ugarte as the ideal player to strengthen their midfield early in the summer but were reluctant to match PSG's asking price of a €60m fixed fee and they believe this deal shows their patient approach to the negotiations has worked, landing an attractive deal for a player they rate highly.
Ugarte made the Copa America Best XI at this summer's tournament in the United States, which further enhanced United's view of him as one of the best young midfielders in the game.

The Uruguayan has been desperate to make the switch since learning of United's interest and he has been left out of PSG's opening Ligue 1 games of the season, with the French giants also in need of a sale to ease their Financial Fair Play concerns after a net spend of more than €400m across the previous two summers.

United had their own issues with FFP and the Premier League's Profit and Sustainability Regulations (PSR) to balance but the impending departures of midfielders Scott McTominay and Hannibal Mejbri, to Napoli and Burnley respectively, have given United breathing room in the final week of the window and PSG's need to sell has led to the two clubs agreeing a permanent deal, having also explored the possibility of a loan with an obligation to buy.

United had also explored alternative options in midfield, but their interest in Real Sociedad's Martin Zubimendi cooled quickly while a return for Sofyan Amrabat was always seen as less attractive than signing Ugarte, who impressed for Uruguay in this summer's Copa America.

Although it has taken a while to agree the terms of a deal, key figures in United's new-look football structure had expressed confidence two weeks ago that they would land Ugarte before this Friday's deadline, which is why he had remained their top target for so long.
Ugarte will become the fifth signing of the window and will take the club's spending to over £200m. He follows the additions of Leny Yoro, Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui.

headline: Manchester United's biggest improvement might be down to the one change Ineos insisted on
body: The nature of Manchester United's defeat to Brighton on Saturday and the doom cycle that never seems far away from this club has made sieving the positives out of the weekend a difficult task.

United have been undeniably better in their first two league games of this season than they were for most of 2023/24, but that has only produced one win and one defeat. And those improvements aren't enough if this team continues to make defensive errors in the way that they did at the Amex.

They let the game open up late on, chasing a win that for the last 10 minutes felt more likely to end in defeat, then allowed themselves to become dishevelled defending an injury-time corner. As Joao Pedro's header flashed past Andre Onana, any immediate desire to alight on positives had been parked.

But that doesn't mean that there weren't things for Erik ten Hag to take from the game. United had more control in the first half, they looked a threat on the break in the second half and Amad took his goal well. But for an unfortunate or unnecessary (depending on your view) offside they would have got at least a point, if not all three.

Maybe the biggest positive from the games against Fulham and Brighton has been the way United have pressed. It has been more aggressive than last season and more structured, which has made it more difficult to play through.

Ten Hag would point to injuries to explain why this element of United's game never really worked last season. They weren't compact enough to press successfully and did so only sporadically. So far this season, there appears a renewed commitment to press the opposition.

It was particularly noticeable on the south coast and in the first half it worked well. Brighton found it difficult to find any rhythm when playing out from the back and twice United won the ball high up the pitch, immediately creating a dangerous attacking position.

The coaching changes made at Carrington this summer might have helped United improve this side of their game. In Rene Hake, they have appointed a coach with a reputation for pressing in the Netherlands. His Go Ahead Eagles side didn't always press during a successful Eredivisie season last term, but when they did they did so with aggression and with success.

You get the impression Hake has made an impact on that side of United's game. It can only benefit Ten Hag having another respected and successful coach helping to fine-tune the way the team presses and if Hake is making his mark, then there should be more to come.

When Ten Hag survived Ineos' end-of-season review in June, one condition of remaining as manager was to rejig his coaching staff. The goalkeepers have spoken highly of the innovative Jelle ten Rouwelaar, the attackers will benefit from working with Ruud van Nistelrooy and Hake's credentials speak for themselves.

It was a change Ineos were keen to see, having decided the dynamic between Ten Hag and his former assistant Mitchell van der Gaag wasn't working for the players. So far, it looks like it's a change that was well worth pushing through and one that Ten Hag deserves credit for embracing.

Ineos will hope what is now an experienced coaching group can continue to develop this team, ironing out those mistakes and decisions that cost United dearly at Brighton. It will also be fascinating to see how they develop as a pressing team this season.

The decision to play Bruno Fernandes as a false nine and Mason Mount just behind him is ideal if you want to press teams. Mount's intelligence to press is excellent and Fernandes has a relentless work rate. He forced Lewis Dunk to concede a very cheap corner on Saturday.

At some point, Ten Hag will start either Joshua Zirkzee or Rasmus Hojlund. Fernandes will then move back and Mount might even drop out of the team. That will be another test of the coaching set-up now in place at Carrington, but the early signs are promising.

headline: Manchester United would be signing the wrong former Man City player with Raheem Sterling deal
body: "He is a Chelsea player, absolutely," said Pep Guardiola about Raheem Sterling last Friday.
Chelsea have made Sterling surplus to requirements and Guardiola poured cold water over the possibility of Manchester City re-signing the winger at his press conference.

"So I just wish him all the best. If you ask me this question when Gundo was in Barcelona, the answer: the same," Guardiola added. City will not re-sign Sterling but it's not beyond the realms of possibility that he returns to Manchester, this time making a move to Old Trafford.
It must be stressed the chances of Sterling making a sensational move to Manchester United are slim, however, stranger things have happened and shocking transfers can happen.
Sterling could move to United in a swap deal for Jadon Sancho, but Juventus are currently frontrunners to sign the 24-year-old and talks would have to collapse for that move to spark.
It's understood Sterling would be open to a move to United if Juventus fail to progress with a deal for Sancho and several dominos would have to fall perfectly for that to materialise.

United have stressed they would only be prepared to do deals that would aid their profitability and sustainability calculations for next year. United also have two wingers on the right and left-hand sides, with Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount also considered as options on the right.

A move to Juventus for Sancho makes sense, given he seems most effective when playing abroad, and it's impossible not to think that United would be signing the wrong former City player if a swap deal with Sterling somehow got the greenlight before the transfer deadline.

Sterling is 29 years old, entering the autumn of his career and has regressed since leaving City. His move to Stamford Bridge hasn't gone as hoped and he hasn't been included in the England squad since the 2022 World Cup, despite having been one of the Three Lions' best performers - he was talismanic at Euro 2020 - throughout Gareth Souhtgate's eight-year tenure.

There's still a feeling that Sterling has more to offer and there could be a huge upside attached to a deal for whoever signs him next, but he has the profile of a player who United signed during the Glazers' time running the club - a player potentially past his best - and would be a risk.
United must look to the future and there has been an obvious change in policy since Sir Jim Ratcliffe's new football structure has been implemented, with younger players being signed.

Ratcliffe wants to sign players with their best years ahead of them and sources admitted that when Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui arrived from Bayern Munich. Sterling's best years seem behind him but that doesn't apply to his Chelsea teammate Cole Palmer.

Palmer is a City academy graduate but famously supported United growing up. A picture of Palmer wearing a 2010/11 United shirt went viral on social media last season and he revealed in an interview that he idolised Wayne Rooney, who was his "hero", when he was a kid.

Carlos Tevez is the most recent player to have represented United and City - Jadon Sancho never played a senior game at the Etihad - and if any player is going to have both clubs on his CV in the near future then it feels likely to be Palmer, who has been outstanding for Chelsea.

Chelsea will do everything they can to keep Palmer. He has just been named the PFA Young Player of the Year following his breakout season in London, he contributed 27 goals and 15 assists last term and Chelsea wouldn't have qualified for European competition without him.

Palmer only signed a contract extension earlier this month to extend his deal until 2033 (yes, really), but Chelsea are a basketcase club with Todd Boehly in charge and he might be forced to leave in the next few years if they aren't matching his ambition in the Premier League and beyond.
It wouldn't be easy or cheap to prise Palmer away from Chelsea, but he is the kind of player that would be perfect for United and he once dreamed of playing in a red shirt.
Sometimes dreams do come true and maybe one day Palmer will play at Old Trafford.

headline: Why Manchester United are selling Scott McTominay as midfielder set for Napoli medical
body: Scott McTominay could undergo a medical in Naples today as he edges closer to completing a £25m move to Serie A side Napoli.

The Manchester United midfielder is set to travel to Italy to finalise a transfer that would see him end his 22-year association with his boyhood club, with the two clubs agreeing a fixed fee for the 27-year-old.

McTominay is attracted by the idea of a new challenge at a club that won the Serie A title in 2022/23 and enjoy significant support. The Scotland international is also keen on the idea of playing in a new league and Napoli boss Antonio Conte had hoped to land him.

United were reluctant to lose their academy graduate, having rejected a £30m offer from West Ham for him last August, before he then went on to enjoy his best season at the club, scoring 10 times last season.

But a combination of McTominay's desire to play regularly and the attraction of selling academy players under the Premier League's financial rules has led to them agreeing a deal with Napoli, having turned down an offer from Fulham earlier in the window.

McTominay has come off the bench in all three of United's competitive games so far this season and although he started the FA Cup final in May, there was an expectation he would have to settle for a bit-part role this season.

United had been unable to sell Casemiro, having considered offloading the Brazilian earlier in the window, and the impending arrival of Manuel Ugarte, coupled with the return to form and fitness of Mason Mount, had left McTominay on the fringes and United were unable to guarantee him the starting position he wanted.

The Premier League's Profit and Sustainability Regulations (PSR) also incentivise the sale of academy players, who go down as pure profit in the books for the financial year. That makes a £25m fee for McTominay more attractive and his departure will help fund the £42.3m move for Ugarte, who is set for his United medical on Tuesday.
McTominay will leave United after 253 appearances, scoring 29 goals and winning the FA Cup and Carabao Cup.

headline: Sancho sold, £30m bid, mystery left-back - Man United next transfer after Manuel Ugarte decided
body: Manchester United's summer transfer window has largely been a success. Things can change quickly entering the final days of the month but Ineos' first big task has so far been bypassed without too much of a hitch.

The early chase for Jarrad Branthwaite didn't descend into saga-like chaos as has been the case previously (see Frenkie de Jong), and despite Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui both taking a bit longer than would have been ideal, two key additions were made. Joshua Zirkzee already looks like a good piece of business for the £35million he cost.

United have recouped some fees back as well, already overtaking their total incomings from last year with the promise of at least one more high (ish) profile exit. In fact, it was 2019 when the club last made this much back from a single summer and that was headlined by Romelu Lukaku.

Should Scott McTominay depart then there's every chance the 2024 window overtakes that. Only the repair job of 2015 and Cristiano Ronaldo's Real Madrid move in 2009 will then be ahead of it. Erik ten Hag may well hope that this year can go the extra step though as it will mean Victor Lindelof is also off the books.

The same is true of Jadon Sancho. A permanent deal away from Old Trafford for him would seal the most lavish selling spree in the club's history. Meanwhile, they have addressed the problem areas in the squad without being tempted by walking red flags and agent offers.

Although Manuel Ugarte carries with him some doubts over mobility and the impact of passing, signing a new midfielder was paramount. What United are getting after a transfer was agreed is exactly what Ten Hag has been after: an anchor to break up and disrupt play. Give the ball to Kobbie Mainoo and move on.

As long as the club doesn't get tempted at the last minute to ditch their well-thought-out summer plans in favour of Raheem Sterling, a quietly impressive window is on the cards. What is needed after Ugarte to complete this though?
Here, Manchester Evening News writers give their thoughts.

On Monday I wrote that it wouldn't surprise me if United did actually go for the Sterling-Sancho swap. Perhaps that was being disingenuous to what Dan Ashworth and Co have actually been working towards this window. United's business hasn't been seamless, it hasn't been quiet, but it has been refreshingly different to past years.
Sterling is nothing United need, especially not in place of Sancho. Really, the less we hear about the Red Devils this week, the better. It really should be just sales and locking up.

McTominay out, fine. For £25million United definitely could have gotten more, and there's a good argument that with European football to come he has a role to play. The decision has been taken to sell him though and getting it over the line rather than running things down too much is a good idea.

Selling Lindelof will be harder. Where is the interest in an ageing defender who has 12 months on his contract and is totally out of favour? If it's not a move to Turkey then really, nobody is going to pay decent money for him.

Sancho is the one to look out for. All parties appear to want the same thing here but getting as close to a permanent resolution as possible would be an achievement. The last thing anyone wants is to be back in this loan-sale purgatory next summer. Take £30million and run.

Ugarte looks to be a sensible signing for United and one which should fix an obvious problem in Ten Hag's squad. The Uruguayan is a younger and more mobile version of Casemiro and should be able to provide a greater platform for Kobbie Mainoo to flourish going forward.

But if a deal cannot be struck to sign Brentford striker Ivan Toney, then the 23-year-old should be United's final summer signing. The priority needs to be getting rid of players who are well past their sell-by date at United - mainly Jadon Sancho and Victor Lindelof.

Selling the Swedish defender may be more difficult due to his injury, however, Sancho clearly has no future at Old Trafford and him staying in Manchester is only going to hurt Ten Hag's team. Overall though it's been a pretty good transfer window for United.

United's signings this summer have made it clear they want to fight for a place in the top four after last season's disappointing eighth-place finish. Their persistence in securing the services of Manuel Ugarte shows just that.

With Ugarte on his way to Old Trafford and the likes of McTominay and Hannibal Mejbri on their way out, United's next focus should be to cash in on Sancho. I struggle to see he has any future at the club despite resolving his differences with Erik ten Hag.

There are some clubs interested in sealing his signature, and I think United should take any good offer that comes their way. Having not played in the first two games of the season, his value could decrease significantly between now and January if he doesn't get minutes throughout the season. It could become increasingly difficult to get a good fee for him.

With the central midfielder box ticked, if you are a United fan the heart would be wanting to make the next transfer an addition to the attack - preferably a centre-forward. However, realistically the next transfer now needs to be a departure.
Mejbri is on the way out but it now seems time to allow Scott McTominay to go. Rio Ferdinand voiced his concerns about the transfer this week and it is understandable.

At the same time, the Reds have an abundance of central midfielders and if Casemiro cannot be sold someone like McTominay was always going to be on the chopping block. The pressure though is ramped up on Erik ten Hag with this strategy considering he is choosing to back Mason Mount to come good instead of a academy graduate.
Only time will tell if this is the right call or not but I think the Scottish international's sale will be next on the agenda for the Reds.

When you look at United's summer transfer business, they have virtually strengthened in every area they needed to apart from one. Erik ten Hag has signed two new centre-backs, a centre forward and a right-back - and is on the verge of signing a new central midfielder in the form of Manuel Ugarte.

I feel that United are a left-back away from a near-perfect window on the incoming front. They desperately need to add a new one to the squad with Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia unreliable due to their damning injury records. Now, deciding which one United should target is the tricky question.

Ben Chilwell does look an obvious option with his Chelsea future uncertain, but United should avoid that one as he has struggled with injuries over the years. Instead, I would suggest Bournemouth's Milos Kerkez. He has been impressive since arriving in the Premier League, and although he would fix the short-term need, he would provide a longer term requirement in that role.

The Manchester Evening News understands that United are only realistically looking to bring in one more player - Manuel Ugarte. While Scott McTominay, Hannibal Mejbri and Jadon Sancho could all leave, the club seem unlikely to spend again this window.

However, if there was one area they could look at, it is at left-back where Luke Shaw is once again injured and Tyrell Malacia is still to return from last summer’s knee operation. A loan deal for an unwanted player is probably more likely than, say, a Ben Chilwell purchase.

The question is whether anyone of that ilk would be worth bringing in given the covering Diogo Dalot, a right-back, has provided astute displays in the role when Shaw and Malacia might be back before long. But then, United fans heard that line last season...

headline: Jadon Sancho and Raheem Sterling swap is dream transfer for Man United, Chelsea and all parties
body: One of the big stories to keep an eye on between now and the end of the transfer window for Manchester United is developments over the futures of both Jadon Sancho and Raheem Sterling.

Sancho is one of the players who could leave United by the end of Friday’s 11pm deadline. The winger spent the second half of last season on loan with Borussia Dortmund after a public falling out with manager Erik ten Hag.

He has since returned to United a clear the air talks have taken place. But he is yet to be included in a matchday squad for the opening two games of the Premier League season, suggesting that a move could be on the cards.

Juventus are interested in signing the winger, with United opening talks with the Turin club over a possible move. But there has also been a suggestion that Chelsea are keen to sign him and could propose a swap deal including Raheem Sterling.

MEN Sport understands that United have held exploratory discussions with Chelsea but are wary of making an approach for the former Man City man, despite his interest in joining the club. Any swap deal is likely to have to see both players reduce their wages for a transfer to go ahead, but if that can be sorted, then it could be an ideal scenario for all parties.

Both players and clubs find themselves in a similar situation with a transfer away from their current sides probably the best outcome. Sterling has been forced to train away from the Chelsea first team after falling out of favour under new head coach Enzo Maresca.
A swap deal would also see both players join the team that they grew up supporting. Back in the summer of 2021, Sancho revealed how he was a Chelsea fan as a child.

He told talkSPORT before Euro 2020: “England hero? I'd probably say Frank Lampard. I was a Chelsea fan growing up, I'm not gonna lie! Didier Drogba and Frank Lampard were my favourite players at the time.
“I just loved Frank Lampard and how he played his game - he was so direct and so composed on the ball and I like things like that.”

Two years earlier, in 2019, Sterling made an admission that he supported United growing up. “I shouldn’t really say this — not now, definitely not now! — but when I was young I was a massive United fan. I had an old United kit, from when they won the last FA Cup,” he told the Mirror.

While a deal could take a lot of hard work from the clubs and some sacrifice from both of the players, it is one that could work if all parties really want it to happen. If it did, it could be the ideal scenario for all involved.

headline: Ivan Toney has new offer after transfer 'agreed' as Manchester United get update
body: Ivan Toney has seemingly got several clubs interested in his signature amid links to Manchester United.

Toney has been credited as a potential target for United on the transfer rumour mill throughout the summer. The Brentford striker has missed the club's opening two matches of the Premier League season amid speculation surrounding his future.

United have already signed Joshua Zirkzee this summer to strengthen their striker options. Zirkzee will compete with Rasmus Hojlund for the centre forward role at Old Trafford this season, but it has not stopped links swirling that Toney could still be a target for United.

The latest report from The Telegraph, though, claims that Chelsea have joined the race to sign Toney in the final days of the transfer window. The article states that the Stamford Bridge club are showing an interest in completing a £50million deal to sign Toney before the window closes on Friday.

This latest twist comes with Toney already having agreed to a move to the Saudi Pro League with Al Ahli. Chelsea are reported to be making a late move to try and convince the England international to remain in the Premier League, but will not be able to match the salary package offered by the club from Saudi Arabia.

United have been linked with a move for Toney all summer, but now that Erik ten Hag has Zirkzee and Hojlund in his squad it remains to be seen if signing another striker is a priority. Brentford boss Thomas Frank has frequently been asked about Toney's future in recent days, with the latest update coming at the weekend.
“Very good question," Frank told reporters on Sunday when asked if Toney was set to leave Brentford. "I actually haven’t asked about that in the last two or three days, so I don’t know actually.
“He trained well all week with a good attitude.”

headline: Man United's new strongest starting XI as Manuel Ugarte transfer deal completes perfect window
body: Manchester United are closing in on the signing of Paris Saint-Germain midfielder Manuel Ugarte.

The Uruguayan will strengthen an obvious weak spot in Erik ten Hag's team by offering greater protection to a back four which has been left endlessly exposed time under the Dutchman. Pressure will now be on the former Ajax boss to deliver better results and ensure United return to the Champions League at a minimum.

Depending on how quickly his medical at Carrington is completed, the 23-year-old could make his United debut in Sunday's huge fixture against Liverpool at Old Trafford. It's set to be a baptism of fire for the Reds' latest recruit.

Ugarte will be United's fifth summer signing in what has been on paper a good window. Striker Joshua Zirkzee and defenders Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui have all been brought in to strengthen Ten Hag's side.

And United will soon have several good options in every position once Ugarte's transfer to the club is completed. The midfielder's arrival could also provide a platform for Kobbie Mainoo to flourish in attacking areas.

The teenager has often looked restricted alongside Casemiro, having needed to make up for some of the spaces the ageing and less mobile Brazilian has left vacant. Whilst there are some doubts over Ugarte's passing ability, the technical quality within United's best-starting line-up should make up for that.

When fit, Diogo Dalot and Luke Shaw are United's best options at full-back whilst De Ligt and Yoro provide a solid base in central defence. Ugarte could then play in a deep-lying role as part of Ten Hag's favoured 4-3-3 formation or alongside Mainoo in a 4-2-3-1.

Fernandes will be able to play further forwards to support a three-pronged attack which includes the pace and skill of Alejandro Garnacho and Amad. Rasmus Hojlund meanwhile is probably still United's best striker.

headline: Man United receive Leny Yoro injury return timeframe after star's hint
body: Manchester United centre-back Leny Yoro has been told he is in a race against the clock to make it back in time for the Christmas period following surgery on his foot.

During the clash with Arsenal in the United States, Yoro picked up an unfortunate foot injury which ended his hopes of being fit and available for the start of the season. Three weeks ago, the Frenchman underwent successful surgery on his injury and is now in the process of undertaking rehabilitation.

Over the bank holiday weekend, the former Lille man hinted he could be returning to United action sooner rather than later as he posted a sand timer emoji along with a picture of him walking out of a tunnel in the Reds' kit. While hope among the fans is that he will be back sooner rather than later, injury expert and Online Slots Real Money ambassador Ben Dinnery is more pessimistic on the defender's return date.

"It is difficult to put a concrete return date in because obviously they do vary depending on the individual and of course other factors," Dinnery told MEN Sport. "Typically we are looking in the region of about 80-90 days to return to playing.

"That could potentially be expedited, we have had players return within that 80 day period but it has on occasions extended way beyond that. That comes down to the type of surgery but historically it has always been around those timeframes - week two you should be doing this, week three you might be doing that.

"However, now it is about incorporating the rehab and the recovery around key points within that so once you get to a certain point, then you progress. A player might take ten days and then somebody else 20 days.

"It really comes down to the individual and Ten Hag will be looking at other factors that will influence [his return] like how things are going on the pitch, where they are in terms of availability of other players, the depth of the squad and how it will be utilised. Maybe there will be opportunities to allow players to go through that full recovery process and be eased back in with the team.

"As we have seen with some players in the past, players sometimes thrust interaction back onto the pitch earlier than they would have liked. But it will certainly be in the realms of that three-month period.

"Anything before then will be a bit of a bonus and if it does extend then United have that duty of care with a player with long-term goals. He is coming into a new environment, new methodologies, new tactics, different intensity of playing football so that transitional phase will take time and will impact, not necessarily the injury but when he will be integrated back into that first team squad and really push for minutes in that United starting XI."

United started with a centre-back partnership of Harry Maguire and Lisandro Martinez at Brighton but Matthijs de Ligt is pushing hard for his first start when Liverpool visit Old Trafford next weekend.

headline: Manchester United trying to arrange two loan departures before transfer deadline day
body: Manchester United are hopeful that loans can be agreed for Sonny Aljofree and Elyh Harrison before the transfer deadline.
Aljofree, 19, and goalkeeper Harrison, 18, have both been identified as young players who would benefit from a loan spell and movement is anticipated before the window shuts.
Clubs who sign United's youngsters on loan must pitch their development plan for the player and talks are progressing for loan moves for both Aljofree and Harrison.

Aljofree signed for Altrincham on a flexi-loan in the January transfer window and spent a few months around the non-league side's squad. The innovative loans allow youngsters to gain senior experience whilst remaining involved in the day-to-day environment at Carrington.
Centre-back Aljofree didn't make an appearance for Altrincham, but the flexi-loan system has been effective elsewhere, helping Sam Mather to develop at Rochdale, for example.
Harrison spent last season playing games for United's Under-21s and Under-18s, and he was named Reserve Player of the Year at the end of the campaign for his superb performances.
The young goalkeeper was brilliant in between the sticks throughout 2023/24 and his shot-stopping display was crucial in the U18s' victory in the PL Cup against Manchester City.
Harrison is a ball-playing 'keeper, whose distribution is a strength, and he did a Cruyff turn with Stockport's striker closing him down at Edgeley Park in the EFL Trophy last year.
There are high hopes for Harrison in the academy and United believe they have a goalkeeper who has the potential to break into the first-team, which will eventually be his target.
Harrison signed his first-ever professional contract with United in March 2023 and that came a year after joining the club from Stevenage Town on a scholarship deal.
The goalkeeper signed his pro deal immediately after celebrating his 17th birthday, which is the earliest possible date a talented young player can be given pro terms.

headline: Manuel Ugarte signs, £50m surprise, four sold - Man United dream end to summer window
body: The clock is ticking towards 11pm on Friday night as Manchester United and fellow Premier League clubs continue to piece together transfer puzzles.

United are gunning for one more first-team signing, and there could be as many as three departures sanctioned by Ineos before the window closes. Scott McTominay, Hannibal Mejbri and Jadon Sancho are being shoe-horned towards the door at Old Trafford, and Manuel Ugarte remains their top inbound target. United and PSG have held positive discussions over his proposed transfer, and there are a number of options still on the table.

United could sign the 23-year-old in a deal similar to Sofyan Amrabat last summer. A loan first move with either an option or obligation to buy appears to be most likely unless McTominay leaves permanently.

Napoli are in the market for him. As for Sancho, meanwhile, United and Italian outfit Juventus are set for talks on a possible switch as August 30 looms ever closer, with Hannibal generating interest from Burnley.

As always, there are plenty of moving parts at play, especially surrounding Ugarte and what effect a departure for McTominay will have on the final stages of that long-standing pursuit. Ugarte has been on the radar for some time, as United seek cover and competition for Casemiro in their engine room.
It's a move that will also allow Erik ten Hag to rotate Casemiro and the emerging Kobbie Mainoo more freely. But what might happen in a dream scenario between now and 11pm on Friday night?

Permanent exits for Hannibal, McTominay and Sancho would seemingly cover any expenditure for Ugarte, while it could even give United extra wiggle room within the budget after deals for Noussair Mazraoui, Leny Yoro, Matthijs De Ligt and Joshua Zirkzee were struck up previously.

A fourth sale - involving Christian Eriksen - might be just the ticket too and especially so if United can generate an interest from the lucrative Saudi Arabia market. In that scenario, there might well be enough scope to press ahead with a 'surprise' addition in attacking quarters - perhaps between Ivan Toney and Evan Ferguson.
Both men are said to be on radar for Ineos and United were previously keeping tabs on Ferguson. Each will almost certainly command a £50million-plus fee if Brighton decide to play ball with Ferguson.

Toney, meanwhile, is seemingly on his way to Saudi Arabia despite Premier League interest. Brentford are thought to be in the process of finalising a deal with Al-Ahli, worth a reported £325,000 per-week to the player.

Armed with extra cash from McTominay, Hannibal, Eriksen and Sancho, United might have enough left - minus the Ugarte fee - to put down a late trump card that could hit their rivals for six this summer.

headline: Man United legend David Beckham sends emotional message after Sven-Goran Eriksson's death
body: Manchester United icon David Beckham has offered a heartfelt homage to Sven-Goran Eriksson, expressing profound emotions over his passing at the age of 76.

The former England skipper took to social media to reflect on their poignant final encounter in Sweden, sharing a personal note that delineated his emotions after his ex-manager's death. In remembrance, Beckham wrote: "We laughed, we cried and we knew we were saying goodbye..

"Sven thank you for always being the person you have always been, passionate, caring, calm and a true gentleman. I will be forever grateful for you making me your captain but I will forever hold these last memories of this day with you and your family."
Ending the tribute, Beckham relayed Eriksson's final words to him: "Thank you Sven, and in your last words to me: 'It will be OK'."

Tributes from across the football world and beyond are flowing in remembrance of Eriksson, including words from Prince William who shared: "Sad to hear about the passing of Sven-Goran Eriksson. I met him several times as England manager and was always struck by his charisma and passion for the game.
"My thoughts are with his family and friends. A true gentleman of the game. W."
Mark Bullingham, the chief executive of the Football Association, shared: "This is a very sad day. He gave all England fans such special memories.

"No one can ever forget the 5-1 victory in Munich against Germany under Sven's guidance. Sven will be rightly recognised and forever remembered for his significant work with the England team, and for his wider contribution to the game.

"On behalf of my colleagues at The FA, past and present, our thoughts are with his friends and family today. He will be much missed, and we will pay tribute to him when we play Finland at Wembley next month."

Eriksson, a man known for his calm demeanour and football intellect, was confined to his hometown of Sunne in Sweden for most of his final days. There, he would enjoy tranquil walks by Lake Fryken, until his health no longer permitted.

In those serene surroundings, he spent precious moments reconnecting with his close ones. His children provided a touching statement regarding their dad's passing: "Our father Sven-Goran Eriksson fell asleep peacefully in his home at Bjorkefors outside Sunne this morning.

"He has for a long time fought bravely with his illness, but now it came to an end. Our thoughts go out to Sven-Goran's father Sven; girlfriend Yaniseth and her son Alcides; to his brother Lasse and wife Jumnong, as well as to all good friends and acquaintances in Sweden and around the world.

"Dad told us at the beginning of this year about his serious illness and received an amazing response from friends and football fans around Europe. He was invited to several football teams in England, Italy, Portugal and Sweden.

"They shared their love for football and for dad. It was unforgettable for both him and us. He expressed his appreciation and joy and stated that such beautiful words are usually only uttered when someone has died.

"We have shared his gratitude and got to experience the wonderful meetings between him, football and all his friends. We thank everyone for these positive memories and your support during his illness.
"We hope that you will remember Sven as the good and positive person he always was in both public and at home with us. Lina and Johan Eriksson."

headline: Manchester United have a major problem even £138m transfer splurge won't solve
body: One major Manchester United issue reared its ugly head again during Saturday's 2-1 defeat at Brighton.

It's been a busy summer at Old Trafford with the arrival of three new defenders, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui as well as a new striker in Joshua Zirkzee. Around £138million in transfer fees has been spent to strengthen Erik ten Hag's squad as new sporting director Dan Ashworth looks to transform how the club buys and sells players.

It's too early to say whether Ashworth's work has had any effect and at least one more signing is set to be made before the window closes on August 30. Paris Saint-Germain's Manuel Ugarte has agreed personal terms with United and the Reds are now close to a breakthrough with PSG.

But one central problem remains which Ten Hag has yet to fix, two games into his third season at the club. United succumbed to defeat at the Amex Stadium from a late stoppage-time winner, scored by Brighton's Joao Pedro.
It followed the late equaliser scored by Bernardo Silva at Wembley in the Community Shield against Manchester City. United went on to lose that fixture as well, on penalties.

Since the start of Ten Hag's first season in charge back in 2022/23, United have lost more games to goals scored in the 90th minute or later than any other English top-flight side (six). It's a startling statistic considering that they had only lost two such matches in the first 30 Premier League campaigns combined.

And with another concentration lapse on Saturday costing United yet again, questions have to be asked of both the manager and players as to why this keeps happening. Is Ten Hag making the right substitutions to see out a close game? Are the players doing enough to stay switched on?
A combination of both is probably why this keeps happening. A lack of goals scored by United players is also a factor.
So many games won by Ten Hag's team have been by a single-goal margin. With so many United results on a knife edge, it's no wonder that wins so quickly turn into draws and draws turn into defeats.
It's an issue which another big summer of big spending hasn't solved. No one should panic at the club after one defeat and there were some positive signs.

However, Ten Hag won't take United far if he and the players continue to make poor decisions at the same major moments which cost United so many results. Improvement takes time but it will remain Groundhog Day at Old Trafford until United's major flaw is fixed.

It truly was the greatest season of all time.

headline: Manchester United player who travelled 500 miles to be snubbed could finally be sold
body: Jadon Sancho made the trip to the south coast on Saturday but was not in the squad.

Sancho was left out of the Manchester United squad for a successive game and watched from the stands as his teammates lost at the Amex Stadium. The decision to omit him from the 20-man squad was ruthless from Erik ten Hag and supporters have no sympathy with the winger's predicament.

"He's here. I had a choice to make and we had some issues," said Ten Hag pre-match. "We need a full squad and he is one of them. He has to compete for his position and from game to game, we will have a look. In the squad, we need every position double because it's a long season."

You would get any odds you liked on Sancho sticking around Old Trafford for the full 2024/25 campaign. Ten Hag was diplomatic when asked about him in pre-season, but the opening two games show his true feelings and the player is in talks to leave before deadline day.

Although United have been looking to sell Sancho, there hasn't been a huge appetite from top sides to sign him, which isn't surprising given his profile and wages. With the transfer window closing on Friday, Juventus and Chelsea have emerged as possible destinations and United are hoping a deal can be struck, most likely with the Serie A side.

Whether that happens remains to be seen. Ten Hag leaving Sancho out of two squads shows he'll only be included when necessary and he must depart to prevent another six months in the cold at Carrington. Sancho wants to leave and has no mention of United on his social media, so a departure is probable although it will be interesting to see how a deal would be structured.

Chelsea have the cash to sign Sancho permanently, which is United's preference, but Juventus are cash strapped and a loan deal with an option or an obligation to sign him once the season has finished is more likely for the Serie A side.

The possibility of Chelsea offering Raheem Sterling in a swap deal with Sancho has also been touted and that would be a huge story considering Sterling spent seven years with Manchester City, helping them to win several Premier League titles before relocating to London.
Yet Juventus are understood to be the front-runners and will hold talks in the coming days to attempt to find a breakthrough in negotiations.
The truth is Sancho has never looked suited to Premier League football and seems to be most effective when playing in Europe, where the play can be slower and more deliberate.
Sancho's best performance in recent memory came against Paris Saint-Germain when he was on loan at Borussia Dortmund last season but he didn't sustain that level during his second stint in Germany.

Nonetheless, a move for Sancho could be viewed as low risk for Juventus because of the potential upside attached. He is clearly still a talented player there and could be an excellent addition if Thiago Motta can coax improvement out of him.

Unfortunately, United have only seen fleeting glimpses of Sancho's talent and his contribution of 12 goals in 83 appearances is a dire record. The close to £73million fee that United paid to sign Sancho felt like a potential bargain, but every goal from the winger has cost £6m without factoring in wages.
If a permanent move to Juventus can eventually be agreed for Sancho, a fraction of that initial investment will be recovered - his time at United has been a disaster.

headline: Manuel Ugarte deal, Jadon Sancho exit - five key transfer decisions Man United face this week
body: This time next week, the transfer window will be closed for business for the summer, and Manchester United's squad could look incredibly different.

A number of deals are in the pipeline ahead of the final five days at Old Trafford, with Erik ten Hag hopeful of adding at least one more signing. United have signed four players this summer with a number of positions strengthened.
Joshua Zirkzee and Leny Yoro arrived early in the window before the double swoop for Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui was completed after weeks of negotiations with Bayern Munich.

Manuel Ugarte remains the club's priority target, and it's understood that United have made progress in a move to sign the Paris Saint-Germain midfielder. However, with time running out in the window, a deal must be completed before Friday's deadline.

PSG are open to negotiating a loan exit for Ugarte if United cannot finance a permanent deal. The figures involved in the deal are yet to be finalised, with the imminent exit of Scott McTominay likely to be a key factor.

The 27-year-old is close to joining Serie A side Napoli, but again, it's another deal that isn't in the final stages with a fee yet to be agreed between the two clubs. United are understood to want £25million for the Scotland international, but a decision could be made to sanction the move.

Jadon Sancho's case is another interesting one with a decision needed over his future. Juventus and more recently Chelsea have been linked with the 24-year-old after he was left out of the matchday squad for the second week running.

Whether or not Sancho leaves United is expected to come down to whether any interested club can reach an agreement with the Reds, and if Ten Hag decides he isn't going to play a part of the 2024/25 season. Should he stay at Old Trafford, the United boss could reintegrate him back into his team.

Midfielder Hannibal Mejbri is attracting interest, and with him out of contract next year, his exit is incredibly likely to be sanctioned. With one signing through the door, Ugarte being the preferred target, United could see at least three players depart.

headline: Casemiro decision, Kobbie Mainoo role - Man United dream line up after Manuel Ugarte transfer
body: Manchester United were beaten in Fergie time during their latest Premier League fixture - but will that 2-1 defeat against Brighton push Ineos back into the transfer market before August 30?
Clubs across the Premier League have until 11pm on Friday night to strike up further business. United have signed Noussair Mazraoui, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Joshua Zirkzee so far this summer.

PSG and Uruguay midfielder Manuel Ugarte is the most likely follow-up addition. The Manchester Evening News understands that progress has been made on discussions between the two clubs involved, and United are said to be edging closer to completing his signature.

United wanted another holding midfielder this summer. Sofyan Ambrabat did not return to Old Trafford following his loan spell from Italian side Fiorentina last season, while Casemiro, Napoli target Scott McTominay and Christian Eriksen were all up for grabs as Ineos continued to mull over potential sales.
As things stand, none of those players have left. However, they are set to be joined by Ugarte.

In that scenario, Erik ten Hag and his backroom staff will have some thinking to do when it comes to his best side. Andre Onana, Lisandro Martinez, Kobbie Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes are pretty much undroppable, while Luke Shaw and Rasmus Hojlund could argue the same as and when fit.

Marcus Rashford and Alejandro Garnacho are close to that bracket, too, despite the latter being consigned to the substitutes bench against Fulham and Brighton. That leaves one or two question marks - at right-back, right centre-back and holding midfield - with Ugarte and Casemiro the two options there.

There's not too much between Diogo Dalot and Noussair Mazraoui at right-back and both of them can operate at left-back anyway with Shaw still on the treatment table. At centre-back, it ought to be a matter of time before De Ligt breaks into the starting XI.

headline: Man United star Leny Yoro shares cryptic injury update after Brighton with possible return date
body: Leny Yoro has hinted at making a Manchester United return sooner rather than later despite being ruled out for up to three months during the pre-season tour of America earlier this summer. The teenage defender was signed for over £50million from Lille in the biggest deal of the window so far for United, but only managed two appearances before suffering a damaging foot injury.

The Frenchman underwent surgery over a fortnight ago and was ruled out for what is expected to be between eight to 12 weeks. Alongside Rasmus Hojlund, who also picked up a knock on the USA trip, United are without two of their star players.

"This is not the start I wanted, but that’s football…" Yoro wrote on Instagram at the time. "The operation went well. Thank you for your many messages of support [black heart emoji]. Now, time for patience and rehabilitation work. See you soon, stronger [first emoji]".

In his absence United have once more turned to Harry Maguire and Jonny Evans whilst Matthijs de Ligt was signed from Bayern Munich. The centre-backs were unable to get Erik ten Hag over the line on Saturday against Brighton though, with Joao Pedro scoring a late winner.

Yoro will be keen to get back onto the pitch in order to help his teammates as quickly as possible but is likely to be out until at least the start of November, with the second international break of the season after the Leicester City trip offering a possible gap before his return.

However, taking to social media once again, Yoro has posted a cryptic but seemingly positive message. Alongside an image of him walking out during the friendly against Rangers in July, Yoro simply added a timer emoji.

Whilst it could be an update indicating his recovery is going well, or even just a form of keeping positive, Yoro's message comes at a good time for United, who are already missing his quality in defence.
