headline: Sir Alex Ferguson has made Scott McTominay thoughts perfectly clear amid Man Utd exit
body: Manchester United's decision to sell Scott McTominay to Napoli may not have gone down well with Sir Alex Ferguson.

The Scotland midfielder, 27, who has been associated with United since the age five, is set for pastures after United accepted a bid of £25.4million from the Italian side. McTominay made 43 appearances last season and started the 2-1 FA Cup final victory over Manchester City in May.

However, the academy graduate, who made his senior debut against Arsenal in 2017, has been deemed expendable by Erik ten Hag, who is now to set to land long-term target Manuel Ugarte from Paris Saint-Germain. After protracted negotiations, United have finally agreed a fee of €50m (£42.3m), with a further €10m (£8.5m) in add-ons.
READ MORE:United agree £42.3m Ugarte deal as transfer approach explained

McTominay's departure will disappoint many at Old Trafford, possibly including Ferguson, who signed the player as a child. Sir Alex has previously hailed the midfielder's big-game temperament, telling the Scottish FA's media channel in 2021: "Scott McTominay is now emerging as one of Man United's big players.
"When you watch Man United pick their team for a big game, McTominay's name is in it. He's a good character, a great trainer. I know a little bit about the boy and I think that's the background."

Comparing McTominay to another United stalwart, Darren Fletcher, Ferguson added: "I signed him when he was seven or eight years of age and he was actually a centre-forward as a kid. He's just sprouted, a little bit like Darren Fletcher. Darren had a few little annoying injuries as he was growing and needed some rest periods and things like that.

"McTominay is of a similar type to Darren - long, lanky, good winner of the ball and a good turn of pace going forward, a great attitude to the game. All these attitudes that Darren Fletcher had, he's got them.

"Even if you go back to my time with Darren, I very seldom left him out of big games, particularly against Arsenal. He was fantastic against Arsenal and Vieira and I had no problems. McTominay is going forward on those guidelines that Darren pursued for a long time at United. It's really rewarding for me to see a Scot coming through."

headline: Manchester United target one signing and three sales ahead of transfer deadline
body: Manchester United's provisional intention is to make one signing and sell three players ahead of Friday's transfer deadline.

United have made progress in a long-gestated move for midfielder Manuel Ugarte, who was left out of Paris Saint-Germain's matchday squad last week. PSG are open to negotiating a loan move for Ugarte if United cannot finance a permanent deal, which is contingent on the departure of Scott McTominay.
McTominay, 27, is inching closer to a move to Napoli. A final fee is not believed to have been agreed, with United holding out for £25m, but the deal is expected to be concluded.

United are looking to sell Jadon Sancho amid interest from Juventus, while Chelsea have been touted as a possible destination for the winger. Sancho, 24, was absent from the United matchday squad for the second week running at Brighton. He still travelled with the squad to the Amex Stadium.

Hannibal Mejbri is generating interest from Championship side Burnley. The 21-year-old has not started for United since November as he was loaned to Sevilla earlier this year in a deal that included an option to buy.
Mejbri is out of contract next year and this week is effectively the last chance United have to obtain a fee for a player they bought for £10m from Monaco when he was a 16-year-old.
United's preference is for straight sales unless a loan deal would help them comply with profitability and sustainability calculations.

headline: Manchester United set for discussions with Juventus over Jadon Sancho
body: Manchester United are set to hold formal discussions with Juventus over the possible sale of Jadon Sancho.

A private jet is scheduled to take off from Manchester for Turin later today amid Juve's firm interest in Sancho. United are prepared to sell Sancho as they have two wingers ahead of him in the pecking order on the right and left-hand side. The 24-year-old's sale would also aid United's profitability and sustainability calculations for next year.

Sancho has been omitted from both of United's Premier League matchday squads so far this season. He still travelled with the squad for the 2-1 defeat to Brighton on Saturday. The former Borussia Dortmund player's only appearance for United in the past year was as a substitute against Manchester City in the Community Shield earlier this month.

Sancho was banished from the United squad last September after he publicly accused manager Erik ten Hag of lying over his omission from the squad for the 3-1 defeat at Arsenal. Dortmund re-signed Sancho on loan from United in January for a loan fee rising to £6.4million and he started in their Champions League final defeat to Real Madrid.

United bought Sancho from Dortmund for £72.9m in 2021 on a five-year contract and would need a final fee of around £29.16m to comply with the amortisation - the cost of Sancho's fee over a five-year period.

Sancho and Scott McTominay could be two high-profile sales to Italy this week, with Napoli closing in on an agreement for the latter. United and Napoli were in dialogue earlier this summer amid the Italian club's interest in Mason Greenwood.

headline: Chelsea plot Jadon Sancho swap deal as Man United close in on fifth summer transfer
body: Chelsea and Juventus are exploring a deal for Manchester United winger Jadon Sancho, according to Sky Sports. The 24-year-old travelled to Brighton for their second Premier League match of the season on Saturday, but was left out of the squad.

Speculation has risen over his future at Old Trafford despite Erik ten Hag 'drawing a line' under their furious row which saw him exiled and sent out on loan to Borussia Dortmund for the second half of last season. Sancho featured off the bench in the Community Shield but hasn't featured in the top flight thus far.

And now, Sancho could leave United before the end of the window with Chelsea and Juventus both showing interest. It's understood that Chelsea's proposal could include a player going the other way. Juventus, on the other hand, want to sign the England international on loan. United prefer to let Sancho leave on a permanent deal but loan has not been ruled out.

Elsewhere, United have reportedly reached an agreement with Serie A side Napoli to sign Scott McTominay. The Athletic have reported that a £25.4million deal has been agreed but the proposal is subject to all parties being satisfied with the player's personal terms. The report adds that United have included a clause which will see them receive a share of any future sale from Antonio Conte's side.

The Scotland international is into the final 12 months of his current deal at Old Trafford, with the option of a further year, but the prospect of a departure for the 27-year-old will see United bank pure profit in the eyes of the Premier League's Profit and Sustainability Rules.

A deal for McTominay is expected to sanction the arrival of Manuel Ugarte from Paris Saint-Germain. The Manchester Evening News understands that United are on the verge of agreeing a deal to sign the Uruguayan after productive talks with the Ligue 1 champions.
Ugarte has been United's top target throughout the summer and despite the two clubs being apart in their valuation at the beginning of talks, a deal is now thought to be imminent.

headline: Erik Ten Hag's Manchester United transfer priority laid bare after Brighton defeat
body: Victory was there for Manchester United in the palm of their hands. Had Alejandro Garnacho's strike not deflected in off Joshua Zirkzee on the line, the Red Devils could have found themselves top of the pile.

It's all hypothetical, but one thing that was made clear in the 2-1 defeat to Brighton was the need for more strength in depth in midfield. Kobbie Mainoo will be at the heart of United's midfield for years to come, an incredible talent at just 19-years-old.

The scheduling of talks regarding a new deal at Old Trafford should come as no surprise to those who've watched his incredible breakthrough. At Brighton, he was one of the few bright sparks in midfield.

According to FotMob ratings, Mainoo top scored in terms of United midfielders with a rating of 6.8, while Casemiro scored just 6.4 and substitute Scott McTominay was rated a lowly 5.8, similarly, Mason Mount took home a rating of just 5.8.

At 32-years-old, it's becoming more evident that United need to look for a successor to Casemiro in the midfield engine room. Although a top player on his day, Ten Hag's side needs to look to the future and take some of the burden off the shoulders of Mainoo.

Although Bruno Fernandes has played in a more advanced role so far this season, akin to a false nine, it's taken away an aspect of creativity in a deeper midfield role. Either they bring in a player who's more defensive-minded, which will free up Mainoo to play further forward, or they sign someone who has more strings to their bow.

They've been linked with a move for PSG midfielder Manuel Ugarte and MEN Sport understand that progress has been made on a deal with the club closing in on the midfielder. The Reds need more control in games, with the defeat at the Amex more akin to a basketball game.

Since the beginning of the 2022-23 campaign, United have lost more Premier League games from goals scored in the 90th minute than any other side - a total of six games. Prior to that, they had only lost two games post 90th minute in their first 30 Premier League campaigns combined.

headline: Manchester United lost to a club with a better plan and Ineos have to make up for lost time
body: There might come a time this season when Manchester United's miserable 2023/24 Premier League season will be consigned to history. We'll stop talking about it, stop using it as a tool for comparison. It suddenly won't feel all that relevant.
For now, with the second stage of the Erik ten Hag era still in its infancy, it's going to condition how we view this team. It's the prism through which United are being judged early in the campaign.

And if the judgements on the opening weekend were encouraging, this was more of a concern. It wasn't quite the collapse we associated United with so often last season. For a lot of the afternoon, they were harder to play against, more structured and more controlled. But they can't kick the addiction to chaos.

United conceded a soft opener in a dull first half and when the game opened up after the break they rode their luck before a 95th-minute winner that felt like it should have been gift-wrapped. Failing to clear a corner and then forgetting to defend half the penalty area during the second phase felt eerily familiar. It came at a time when Brighton's pressure had been building.

So a point that would have felt like it added belief to Ten Hag's new side vanished and the familiar questions returned. This team do look better, but are the improvements enough? They have got better as a pressing team and are more compact, but they aren't creating enough chances and are making defensive errors. It puts plenty of pressure on the Old Trafford game with Liverpool next week.

Ten Hag's side actually won here in May but that felt like an anomaly. Brighton had won four of their last five Premier League meetings and in so many ways they are a club that United are now trying to ape under Ineos. They are United's bogey team but in so many ways their template as well.

They need to be an elite version of Brighton but that is the aim. This is a club that gets so much right. Lose one highly-rated manager and they replace him with another that no Premier League club had considered. When he goes that, just repeat the process.

After an exodus of players from the Amex in recent years it has been a more stable summer and they have spent more than United on new arrivals. All of them are young players with obvious resale value and many of them creative signings. There are players coming in front Mainz, Nordsjaelland and Gothenburg.

It's noticeable that under 31-year-old head coach Fabian Hurzeler they play a similar style to Roberto De Zerbi. The wingers still fly forward, there are still two strikers and they try to bait the press when deep.

That continuity and the transfer market hit rate is the envy of almost every 'big' club. United are no different. For too long they have lurched from one style to another, from one fad to the next. If either team deserved to win the game it was the Seagulls and in Hurzeler they seem to have another manager destined for the top.

It will stick in Ten Hag's craw that he was beaten by a coach 23 years younger than him. He might have survived the summer but the pressure could easily increase early in the season and he has to avoid results like this.

Sticking with him is the biggest gamble of Sir Jim Ratcliffe's ownership. United are starting to get things right under Ineos and their summer transfer activity looks smart. They can't afford many more games like this.

headline: Managing Manchester United: Manuel Ugarte transfer, Jadon Sancho decision and Ivan Toney hijack
body: It has been a busy summer for Manchester United with it being the first under the ownership of Sir Jim Ratcliffe and INEOS.
The club have so far brought four new players into the squad. Striker Joshua Zirkzee has been joined by defenders Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt, and Noussair Mazraoui.

Three of the four made their debuts in last weekend’s season opener against Fulham at Old Trafford. Zirkzee came off the bench to make an immediate impact, scoring the only goal of the game in a 1-0 win.
There is now less than a week of the transfer window left. Clubs will be working to sort any last minute deals, and that will be the same at Old Trafford in terms of possible incomings and outgoings.
So what could the last few days of the transfer window look like for United? MEN Sport has taken a look at some of the things that could happen if we were in Ten Hag’s shoes.

The deal that looks the most likely between now and the end of the transfer window is the signing of Paris Saint Germain midfielder Manuel Ugarte. United have been linked with an interest in the Uruguayan for most of the summer.

The club walked away from negotiations due to PSG’s high asking price, but it seems that the talks have now continued. MEN Sport understand that progress has been made on a deal with the club closing in on the midfielder.
The priority will now be to get a deal over the line before next Friday’s deadline. The 23-year-old has been targeted as a potential long-term partner alongside Kobbie Mainoo in United’s midfield.

Sancho has been linked with a move away from Old Trafford since his return from a loan spell with Borussia Dortmund at the start of the summer. The winger moved on loan to Germany for the second half of last season after a public falling out with manager Erik ten Hag.

That issue has now been resolved, but Sancho continues to be linked with an exit. It is said that Juventus are interested in signing the player on a permanent deal, but the financial aspects could prove to be a stumbling block.

United are said to want a fee of around £40 million for Sancho. If they can get that, then sorting a deal earlier rather than later would be a massive plus for the team, and allow them to reinvest the fee in the final days of the window.
The club however, may have to settle for a loan deal. They will hope that any temporary switch will include an obligation to buy at around the asking price.

If United are successful in selling Sancho for around the £40 million mark, then the money could be reinvested into a possible hijack of a deal for Brentford striker Ivan Toney. The England man was left out of the Bees’ opening game of the season last week due to the transfer speculation over his future.

He has been heavily linked with a move to Saudi Arabia with Brentford turning down a £35 million bid from Al-Ahli. United have just two recognised strikers in their current squad in Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee, with the former currently injured.

It is said that Brentford will demand a fee of around £50 million for Toney in the final days. Although United are unlikely to make a move with MEN Sport understanding that the only likely incoming is that of Ugarte.

headline: Ivan Toney transfer 'agreed' as Manchester United get update
body: Brentford striker Ivan Toney's transfer could reportedly be completed within the next 24 hours after he again was left out of the Bees' squad for their trip to Liverpool.

The England international's future at the London club has been in doubt all summer after Toney made it abundantly clear last season that he wanted a 'big move'. With Manchester United looking for strikers in the summer transfer window, the 28-year-old was inevitably linked with a switch to Old Trafford.

United manager Erik ten Hag added Joshua Zirkzee to his team but after Rasmus Hojlund's injury, speculation crept up again that the Reds could make a last-ditch bid for his services. Last weekend, Toney missed out on the Brentford team that beat Crystal Palace and he was not named in the squad at Anfield on Sunday.

Explaining to Sky Sports the reason for Toney's absence, his manager Thomas Frank said: "The status is the same as last week. Things are going on with transfer speculation so the decision is the same.
"He is training well, there is no problem. I’d rather focus on the game and the players that are playing instead of talking about him."

Despite all the talk surrounding the Reds, Toney's most likely destination is Saudi Arabia. According to journalist Ben Jacobs, Al Ahli have agreed terms with the forward over a move to the Middle East.

The Saudi Pro League's vice chairman Saad Al-Lazeez and sporting director Michael Emenalo are thought to be in London to iron out the final details of the contract. As for United, they persisted with no starting striker in the defeat to Brighton and Hove Albion but switched things up at half-time when Zirkzee was introduced.

headline: Erik ten Hag forced into brutal Marcus Rashford decision after Manchester United point made
body: Marcus Rashford is the odd one out in the Manchester United frontline after Amad scored his first goal of the season against Brighton and Hove Albion.

Alejandro Garnacho got off the mark in the Community Shield versus Manchester City, while Joshua Zirkzee turned home the winner against Fulham on opening night. Both players were also involved in United's second disallowed goal on the south coast, with Rashford firing home the first called back for offside.

But unlike them and Amad, the former England international has not been able to celebrate since finding the back of the net with a penalty against Real Betis during the club's pre-season tour. That was his first since the extra-time equaliser against Liverpool in mid-March.
READ MORE:Ugarte transfer complete, Sancho sold and Mejbri decisions - United dream 25-man squad
Amad also iconically scored in that FA Cup quarter-final tie, a winner which Garnacho assisted. However, since then, it is fair to say those two have faired better than their teammate.

Garnacho scored twice the following month against Chelsea and assisted Harry Maguire's equaliser against Sheffield United before finishing the season by opening the scoring in the FA Cup final. Amad did not feature at Wembley but assisted the opener and scored the second in United's final home match versus Newcastle United.
They took advantage of Rashford being out with an ankle injury. However, he has not done the same despite Garnacho returning to pre-season late after winning the Copa America with Argentina.

Amad kicked on in pre-season, scoring against former club Rangers and also versus Betis. Rashford did assist Casemiro's goal in that friendly and Rasmus Hojlund's against Arsenal, but that creativity has not translated to the season itself.

Garnacho playing a combined 90 minutes across the Community Shield and Premier League this month should mean he is ready to start next weekend against Liverpool. Amad would have been the likely player to make way, with the Argentine replacing him against City and Fulham.

But the fact manger Erik ten Hag kept him on and withdrew Rashford for Garnacho against Brighton may mean the bench is beckoning for Rashford. It will be a brutal decision due to his status at the club and being among the best-paid players in the squad - and his past performances against Liverpool - plus the fact that it is likely too late for Rashford to secure a move away, but it is one Ten Hag may have to make based on current form.

headline: Manchester United's plan for Sekou Kone revealed after agreement for wonderkid transfer
body: Manchester United have agreed a deal to sign defensive midfielder Sekou Kone in this summer window.
Kone currently plays for Guidars FC and impressed playing for Mali at the Under-17 World Cup in December, but he's set to complete a transfer to United before deadline day.
Although Erik ten Hag is in the market to sign a defensive midfielder and talks for Manuel Ugarte are progressing, the plan is for Kone to join up with the Under-21s.

It's understood the 18-year-old is considered as a player with high potential by United staff and he'll spend time training with the first-team at Carrington, which means he could be fast-tracked if he demonstrates he can operate at the level required around the senior group.
Manchester is close to 2,500 away from the African nation Mali and United will help Kone integrate into life in England as he settles into his new surroundings at a young age.
When United signed Alejandro Garnacho as a teenager in 2020, he undertook intensive English lessons and was given access to documentaries on the club and Manchester.
The same treatment will be given to Kone and more because Garnacho signed during the pandemic, which limited the care the club could give him after signing from Atletico Madrid.
Travis Binnion is the U21 manager at United and he will oversee Kone in a youth programme that will provide him with challenges in the EFL Trophy and in the Premier League 2.

Kone started his career with the JMG academy in Bamako, Mail, following in the footsteps of Tottenham Hotspur and Mali international Yves Bissouma. Mali beat Argentina to claim a third-place finish at the U17 World Cup in Indonesia and Kone played a pivotal role in that success.
United have also signed youth striker Chido Obi-Martin from Arsenal this summer and they continue to add talent to their academy to remain at the forefront of youth development.

headline: Who is Jim Thwaites? The 16-year-old training with Manchester United first team ahead of Brighton
body: Manchester United are stepping up their preparations for the first away game of the 2024/15 Premier League season.

Erik ten Hag’s side started the campaign on a positive note with new signing Joshua Zirkzee getting the only goal of the game in last Friday’s 1-0 Premier League win over Fulham as the team kicked off the new campaign. Concentration now turns to the trip to Brighton.
United take on the Seagulls at the AMEX Stadium on Saturday (12.30pm kick-off). Fabian Hurzeler’s side started with a 3-0 win over Everton last weekend, leaving them at the top of the early table.

Ahead of the game, Ten Hag has been putting his first-team squad through their paces. Included in the group was teenager Jim Thwaites, who at just 16 is considered as one of the club’s leading prospects.
So who is Thwaites? MEN Sport has taken a closer look at the youngster.

Thwaites is a 16-year-old central midfielder who has come up through the youth teams at Old Trafford. He was one of 10 players to sign a first-year scholarship deal earlier this summer, with young players not able to sign professional deals until they are 17 years old.

He featured for the club’s U16, U18, and U21 sides last season, winning the Goal of the Season award at both U16 and U18 levels. He made nine appearances for the U18s, his goal being a crucial equaliser in the 2-2 draw with Derby County.

His two appearances for the development squad came as a second-half substitute in the Premier League 2 clashes against Derby and Middlesbrough. This year he is expected to be given a prominent role in the U18s side and awarded with the experience of joining in with first-team training.

Taking to Instagram after his Goal of the Season awards, the teenager promised there was ‘more to come’ in the upcoming campaign. Sharing a clip of both of the goals on his Instagram, he wrote: “Delighted to get both U16 and U18 goal of the season. More to come next season…”

He has also given his response to training with the United first team for the first time. On Wednesday night he posted a picture of his boots on his Instagram story with a caption reading: “Good first session with the first team.”

headline: Manchester United include 16-year-old in first-team training after scoring two wonder goals

headline: Manchester United make decision on former Liverpool talent after electric start for academy
body: Manchester United youngster Ethan Ennis will not leave on loan in this transfer window.
The Manchester Evening News exclusively revealed last month that Ennis had signed a new United contract, as his previous deal with the club expired in the summer of 2025.
It's understood United have decided it's best for Ennis' development for him to spend the first half of the season with the Under-21s before the situation is assessed in January.
Ennis returned from a lengthy spell on the sidelines due to rupturing the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) in his knee in October but has impressively got back up to speed.
The youngster ended last term with a flourish and looked sharp in friendlies against Rosenborg and Rangers this summer, coming on from the bench under the eye of Erik ten Hag.
Ennis scored in the U21s' opening game of the season against Arsenal and scored again on Tuesday night when producing the goal that sparked a 3-2 comeback against Barnsley.
The 19-year-old has started the new season in great form, scoring two goals in two appearances, and his professionalism in and out of training hasn't gone unnoticed at United.

Although some speculated that Ennis would leave on loan this summer after signing his new contract, he will continue to be an integral U21 player and could be allowed to leave on a temporary deal to challenge himself in a senior environment in the January window.
There were high hopes for Ennis when United signed him from rivals Liverpool and his minutes were carefully handled last season, which helped him return to full fitness.
Ennis signed his first professional contract immediately after celebrating his 17th birthday and only the most highly regarded academy talents are given pro deals so quickly.
The Chesire-born lad scored 10 goals in 19 appearances for United's Under-18s in 2021/22, his first full season at the club, and his finishing ability is one of his finest qualities.

headline: New Man United signing explains reason for summer transfer as clear promise made
body: New Manchester United signing Dominique Janssen says the club's "big ambitions" helped convince her to make the switch to Marc Skinner's side and believes the Reds' FA Cup success last term will drive them on to more silverware.

Janssen joined United on a three-year deal with the option of an additional 12 months earlier in the summer following the expiration of her contract with Wolfsburg. The Netherlands defender returns to the Women’s Super League (WSL) having previously spent four seasons at Arsenal, with whom she won the league title, the FA Cup and two League Cups.

Reflecting on her decision to join the Reds in her first interview with the club, Janssen said: "I knew a little bit (about United) and their fan base is like crazy, it's really nice to get to know them and to see how the club has developed and also to see where we can go with the team.

"The club have big ambitions. The growth they have been making the past six years since they have started has also been really good. Of course there will also be some bumps in the road which I heard from the girls as well that last season was maybe was not the easiest season.

"But it's about knowing the up and downs are just part of the journey and it's so exciting to see where we can go in the next few years. That's what also drew me to the club, the potential we have in the next few years. I want to help the club and I want to do it together with the girls."

Last season was a disappointing one for United as they finished fifth in the WSL, winning just 10 of their 22 league games. However, the Reds did manage to secure the club's first major women's trophy by beating Tottenham Hotspur to the FA Cup and Janssen believes this will spur Skinner's side on to achieving more success next term.
"That's the goal," she said. "I'm hungry for more trophies and I think also they got last year the first trophy, so I think they're hungry for more trophies as well."

The defender added: "I think it has changed a lot. I have looked a little bit at the games and seeing how things are going and you see that the league is very competitive. You need to be at the top of your game every single weekend. You cannot play at 80 per cent because even the teams that are lower in the table can still beat you."

United will kick off their new WSL campaign against West Ham United on September 21 and Janssen is relishing the chance to get her first taste of representing United at Old Trafford. She said: "I think first of all just playing at Old Trafford, obviously it's called the Theatre of Dreams so I'm very excited to play there and see how many people come as well."

headline: Man United star makes trophy vow after beating Man City and Chelsea rivals to 'unbelievable' award
body: England midfielder Grace Clinton says her aim is to win trophies with Manchester United after being voted PFA Young Player of the Year.

The 21-year-old joined the Reds from Everton in 2022 though she is yet to make a competitive appearance for the club, having since enjoyed loan spells at both Bristol City and Tottenham Hotspur. Clinton excelled for the latter last term, scoring four goals and assisting four others in 20 Women's Super League (WSL) appearances and playing an integral role in Spurs’ charge to their first ever Women’s FA Cup final, though she was ineligible to play against her parent club and eventual victors United at Wembley.

Her impressive form saw her receive her first senior England call up earlier this year. She made her first full start against Austria after two appearances off the bench, and duly made an impact with her first international goal in a 7-2 win for the Lionesses.

Clinton impressed so much at Tottenham that the club were keen to make her stay in the capital permanent. “She cannot stay because she’s not a part of us next year," manager Robert Vilahamn told The Athletic in April. "But if you ask me if I want to buy her, there would be a high potential I want to do that."

However United boss Skinner has always been unequivocal in his stance on the 21-year-old, insisting that her long-term future lies in Manchester. "All I hear is Tottenham want to keep Grace, of course they want to keep Grace," he said when quizzed on the club's plans for Clinton back in May. "She's a fantastic player.

"We don't get the credit that we identified her qualities at Everton, we brought her to Manchester United, gave her six months, sent her on loan at Bristol – she got experience. She then went on loan to Tottenham to get more experience. I don't think people recognise that – there is a plan for each individual we bring into the club.
"With Grace, it's absolutely worked. I want to bring her back to the club and be part of what we're doing because I think she has a huge say in how we'll play."

And Clinton has now voiced her commitment to the Reds, insisting her ambition is to add more silverware to the club's collection. "To go to Tottenham and get confidence was just amazing," she said at the start-studded awards ceremony on Tuesday night. "And to improve obviously personally. The aim is always to win trophies with Manchester United."

On her award, Clinton added: “It’s such an honour to be voted by the unbelievable players that play in this league. It’s the best league in the world. “To go out on loan, learning as a young player and being recognized is lovely. I’ve played with confidence and when you play with that then you see the best version of a player. Tottenham have been a massive part of my journey, and I can’t thank them enough. Goals and visualisation are important to me but most of all just enjoying playing. If I’m enjoying myself then I play my best football.”

Clinton also featured in the PFA Women's Team of the Year, alongside Manchester City stars Khadija 'Bunny' Shaw, Yui Hasegawa, Lauren Hemp, Khiara Keating, Alex Greenwood, Laia Aleixandri. She beat out a host of talented players to earn the award with Lauren James, Aggie Beever-Jones, Khiara Keating, Maya Le Tissier and Jess Park among the names on the Top Six shortlist.

headline: Man United have already made history but hard work is only just beginning
body: With a deft back-post finish, Lizzie Arnot wrote her name into the annals of Manchester United history. The date was August 19, 2018 and the Scotland international ensured the Reds' long-awaited renaissance began in style by netting a last-gasp winner against bitter rivals Liverpool in the League Cup.

The setting - in front of just 829 fans at an overcast Prenton Park - belied the enormity of the occassion. This was United's first competitive game in 13 years, their first competitive outing since the Glazer regime opted to disband their senior women's team after deeming it not to be part of the club's "core business".

The team was peppered with familar faces. Alex Greenwood, now captain of Manchester City, teed up Arnot to score the winner. Lauren James, who returned to childhood club Chelsea for what was - in 2021 - a British record fee, started in midfield, while current United stars Ella Toone, Millie Turner and Leah Galton also featured.
"For a team that has only been together for six weeks they weathered the storm quite well," manager Casey Stoney told BBC Radio 5 Live after the game.

"I recruited from the second tier, they've stepped up and shown they are more than capable of playing a level above that. There's no pressure from the club to get promotion but these players want to be playing in the top flight. They're history makers now."

In spite of Stoney's measured assessment of United's ambitions, the Reds did achieve promotion at the first time of asking, subsequently finishing fourth in their first season in the Women's Super League (WSL). And now, just six years on from that League Cup victory over Liverpool, United are a card-carrying member of the top flight's elite.

Stoney's departure in the summer of 2021 was a blow but her replacement, former Birmingham City boss Marc Skinner, has presided over the most successful period in the club's history. In 2022/23, the Reds took the title race to the final day, posting a club-record points tally in the process while also reaching the FA Cup final.

Last term, despite a disappointing fifth-place finish in the WSL, United beat Tottenham Hotspur to the FA Cup trophy; a reality which would have seemed inconceivable on that momentous afternoon at Prenton Park more than half a decade ago.

While the Reds have come a tremendously long way since then, it is fair to say this summer has not been without its challenges. First came the revelataion that Skinner had been handed a one-year contract extension - a decision which was not universally popular with the United fanbase.

Then came the exodus of some of the club's biggest stars. England goalkeeper Mary Earps left to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG), citing United's transitional state and her own ambition to compete for more silverware as her chief motivating factors. Club captain Katie Zelem also departed on a free transfer, as did fan-favourite striker Lucia Garcia.

All of this unfolded has against the backdrop of Sir Jim Ratcliffe's barely concealed apathy towards Skinner's side. The INEOS chief gave a tone-deaf interview to Bloomberg, in which he conceded plans for the women's team were "TBC".

This was swiftly followed by United Women being ousted from their state-of-the-art Carrington training facility to make way for the men's team while their own building gets a revamp, though it is understood Skinner and his players will still have access to all the necessary facilities.

Still, the emergence of reports citing concern from the Professional Footballers Association (PFA) and of agents' apparent unwillingness to throw their players into the maelstrom that is Manchester United have been concerning.

That said, the Reds have recruited shrewdly in the transfer market, with the acquisition of Brighton & Hove Albion striker Elisabeth Terland and Swedish defender Anna Sandberg, in particular, inspiring excitement, while the appointment of Dan Ashworth as sporting director inspires hope of tangible change at the club.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said in an open letter to supporters last month.

"Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United. Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that.
“Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."

Indeed, six years on from that win over Liverpool, United now have all the ingredients in place to be truly successful. The Reds may already have made history in the years since their reformation but, with the WSL set to be more competitive than ever next term, it is clear the hard work is only just beginning.

headline: Dan Ashworth makes encouraging Man United gesture after Sir Jim Ratcliffe admission
body: Dan Ashworth has met with Manchester United Women's players after a turbulent summer for Marc Skinner's side.

United have come in for criticism of late number after a number of high-profile players, including England goalkeeper Mary Earps and captain Katie Zelem, were allowed to leave the club on free transfers, while co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe sparked controversy when he admitted plans for the women's team were "TBC".

However, Ashworth's long-awaited arrival from Newcastle United last month has offered some cause for optimism, with the sporting director having previously been a huge advocate for the growth of the women's game during his time with the Magpies and in his previous role at Brighton & Hove Albion. And the 53-year-old has now met with Skinner and his players as they ramp up their pre-season preparations at St George's Park.

Pictures shared on the club's website show Ashworth giving a speech to the women's first-team squad and shaking hands with stars such as Ella Toone and Millie Turner. This comes after he outlined his vision for the Reds in an open letter to supporters.

"Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United.

headline: Manchester United confirm 'insane' summer transfer as overhaul continues
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of Canada international Simi Awujo on a three-year deal.

The 20-year-old midfielder joins the Reds from the United States collegiate system, where she represented the University of Southern California’s USC Trojans. Awujo made her senior international debut for Canada at 18-years-old and has 19 caps for her country to date, reaching the quarter-finals of this summer’s Paris 2024 Olympic games.

Reflecting on her move to Manchester, Awujo said: “To say that I’m a professional footballer for Manchester United is insane. I’m so excited for the season ahead, what the future holds here and just to be a red devil. I cannot wait to play in front of the great Manchester United fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “Simi is an exciting young talent who we are delighted has chosen to continue her football journey with us here at Manchester United. Our wonderful fans can expect a midfielder with international pedigree, who will only develop further in our competitive English game.”

Awujo is United's fifth signing of the summer following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Melvine Malard, Elisabeth Terland and Anna Sandber.
